{{Infobox |above = [[File:Flag of Mongolia.svg|40x40px]]  '''Administrative law in Mongolia |abovestyle=border-bottom:1px solid #FF0000;" colspan="2" |headerstyle = color:black;background:#FF0000; |labelstyle = color:black;background:white; |datastyle = color:black;background:white;align:center; |header1 = Mongolian Laws |data2 = [[Constitution of Mongolia]]
[[Mongolian nationality law]]
Administrative law in Mongolia
[[LGBT rights in Mongolia]] |header3 = [[Mongolia]] |data4 = [[File:Mongols-map.png|250x250px]] }} {{Administrative law}} {{Main|Administrative law|Mongolia}} '''Administrative law in [[Mongolia]]''' is the body of law that governs the activities of [[Government agency|administrative agencies]] of the [[Mongolian government]]. These activities include [[rulemaking]], [[adjudication]], or the [[Rulemaking#Rulemaking and the courts|enforcement of a specific regulatory agenda]]. ==History of administrative law== Administrative law in [[Mongolia]] developed as the country transited from the [[Mongolian People's Republic|Soviet-era]] to a [[Mongolia|democratic state]]. The development can be divided into two main stages. ===Soviet-era=== '''During the Soviet-era:''' *Three central agencies of state administration were formed. {{Citation | last = Butler | first = William | title = The Mongolian Legal System (Studies on Socialist Legal Systems) | year = 1982 | place = | publisher = Springer | page = | isbn = 978-90-247-2685-1 |url=https://www.amazon.com/Mongolian-System-Studies-Socialist-Systems/dp/9024726859/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1317198515&sr=1-1 | accessdate = 2011-09-28 }} *The Mongolian People’s Government became the highest agency of state power, with the powers to implement reforms in law, ministries and judiciary. (Primacy of the [[One-party state|one-party State]] upheld.) ===Post Soviet-era=== '''After democratisation:''' *Major reforms of administrative structures and practices of government agencies as part of the transition into a [[market economy]] {{Citation | last1 = Nixson | first1 = Frederick I. | last2 = Walters | first2=Bernard | title = Administrative Reform and Economic Development in Mongolia, 1990-1997: A Critical Perspective | year = 1999 | publisher = ''[[Review of Policy Research]]'', 1999, vol. 16, | pages = 147–175 | isbn = 978-90-247-2685-1 |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1541-1338.1999.tb00873.x/epdf?r3_referer=wol&tracking_action=preview_click&show_checkout=1&purchase_referrer=www.google.com&purchase_site_license=LICENSE_DENIED_NO_CUSTOMER | accessdate = 2011-09-28 }} url to full text restricted to subscribers *Founded the Management Development Program (MDP) in 1994 with the support of [[United Nations]] to implement more extensive reforms in **[[Public administration]] and [[civil service]] **[[Decentralization]] and local administration strengthening **Private sector development *The formation of [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]]. {{Citation | last1 = Sanders | first1 = Alan J.K. | title = Mongolia's New Constitution: Blueprint for Democracy | year = 1992 | publisher = ''[[Asian Survey]]'' Vol. 32, No. 6 (Jun., 1992) | pages = 506–520 | isbn = 978-90-247-2685-1 | jstor = 2645157 }} url to full text restricted to JSTOR subscribers *Substantial reduction of the [[President of Mongolia|President’s]] power in deference to [[State Great Khural|Parliament]], the Cabinet and the Law on the Presidency. *Greater autonomy for local administration on the principle of ‘self-government and central guidance’. *[[Executive (government)|Executive power]] circumscribed by the [[Constitution of Mongolia|Constitution]], which in turn is enforced by a newly established [[Constitutional Court of Mongolia|Constitutional ''Tsets''(Court)]]. Further progression: *Rapid implementation of MDP reforms initially, but progress soon stalled *United Nations adapted the [[New Zealand]] model of administrative reforms for Mongolia which served to further eliminate conflict of interests in the restructuring of administrative units. ==Sources of law in Mongolia== ===Constitution=== The [[Constitution of Mongolia|Constitution]] is the supreme source of law in [[Mongolia]]. Influenced by the [[Civil Law (Legal System)|Romano-Germanic civil law system]], [[Mongolia]] recognizes [[Codification (law)|written law]] as the main source of law. The [[Constitution of Mongolia|Constitution in 1992]] abolished [[Marxism-Leninism|Marxism-Leninist ideology]] and laid out the [[democracy|democratic]] principles of the [[separation of powers|separation of state powers]] and the [[fundamental rights|fundamental rights of citizens]].[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/details.jsp?id=3039 "Constitution of Mongolia, at WIPO] [[File:Article 10.jpg|thumb|left|Article 10 of 1992 Constitution of Mongolia]] ===Statutes=== [[Statutes]] are a primary source of law. There is an accepted distinction between normative acts (which regulates conventional social behavior) and non-normative acts. {{Citation | last1 = Butler | first1 = William | title = The Mongolian Legal System (Studies on Socialist Legal Systems) | year = 1982 | publisher = Springer | pages = | isbn = 978-90-247-2685-1 | url = https://www.amazon.com/Mongolian-System-Studies-Socialist-Systems/dp/9024726859/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1317199982&sr=1-1 | accessdate = 2011-09-28 }} The hierarchy of state agencies is a factor that determines which agency will govern which act. Only the [[State Great Khural|legislative branch of the government]] has the right to make laws. ===Legal Customs=== Mongolia’s nomadic past and unique living habits has elevated the importance of [[Custom (law)|customs]] as a source of law. Throughout generations, customs that complement existing legal norms have prevailed. However, as there is lack of substantial evidence in literature, it is uncertain if Mongolian courts will recognize customs in the absence of legislation. ===International Law=== The position of [[international law]] as a source of law in [[Mongolia]] was elevated following the [[Constitution of Mongolia|1992 Constitution of Mongolia]].[http://www.lexadin.nl/wlg/legis/nofr/oeur/lxwemon.htm Legislation, Mongolia] Lexadin, The World Law Guide According to Art 10(3) of the Constitution, international treaties to which Mongolia is a party eventually becomes domestic law, unless they contradict the Constitution itself. ==Areas of administrative rulemaking== {{Clickable map of Mongolian provinces|left|}} [[Mongolia]] is divided administratively into 21 ''[[Aimag (country subdivision)#Mongolia|aimags]]'' (provinces) according to Article 57 of the [[Constitution of Mongolia|Constitution]].[http://www.servat.unibe.ch/icl/mg00000_.html ''The Constitution of Mongolia''] The Constitution vests the governor and parliament of the [[Provinces of Mongolia|provinces]] with self-administrative powers. The [[Politics of Mongolia#Executive branch|Government of Mongolia]] is vested with the executive power of [[Mongolia]] and is composed of Ministries under the direction of the Cabinet and the [[Prime Minister of Mongolia|Prime Minister]]. The roles, duties and responsibilities of these government agencies are usually defined by codified statutes. The following lists the ministries within the [[Politics of Mongolia#Executive branch|Government]] with significant existing bodies of regulations: [[File:Nalaikh 11.JPG|thumb|left| A miner in Mongolia.]] ===Ministry of Mineral Resources=== With respect to mining activity in Mongolia,[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mg.html "CIA World Factbook"] the Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy, their subsidiary government and the local ''aimag'' government have responsibilities regulated by the Mineral Laws of Mongolia.[http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law40.pdf "The Mineral Laws of Mongolia, Articles 9, 10, 11 and 12"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324085956/http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law40.pdf |date=March 24, 2012 }} For instance, the local administrative body of an ''aimag'' has a duty to monitor compliance with respect to environmental reclamation, health and safety regulations under Article 12 of the Mineral Laws. ===Ministry of Environment=== The duties and powers of the Ministry of Environment in Mongolia are largely governed by the Environmental Protection Law of Mongolia.[http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law12.pdf "Environmental Protection Law of Mongolia"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324090038/http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law12.pdf |date=March 24, 2012 }} Furthermore, other laws such as the Law of Mongolia on Land also empower the land departments of individual ''aimags'' in the enforcement of the land laws of Mongolia.[http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law28.pdf "Law of Mongolia on Land"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324090048/http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law28.pdf |date=March 24, 2012 }} ===General Customs Office=== The General Customs Office of Mongolia and their State Customs Inspectors have to abide by the Customs Law of Mongolia[http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law10.pdf " Customs Law of Mongolia"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324090058/http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law10.pdf |date=March 24, 2012 }} when they enforce customs laws. In addition, they are also empowered to impose tariffs on goods under the Customs Tariff Law of Mongolia.[http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law09.pdf " Customs Tariff Law of Mongolia"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324090109/http://www.investmongolia.com/fifta/law/law09.pdf |date=March 24, 2012 }} ===Nuclear Energy Agency=== The Nuclear Energy Agency is also bound by the Law of Mongolia on its nuclear-weapon-free status, to only use nuclear energy for non-military purposes.[http://www.opanal.org/NWFZ/Mongolia/Mlaw_en.html "Law of Mongolia on its nuclear-weapon-free status"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331162033/http://www.opanal.org/NWFZ/Mongolia/Mlaw_en.html |date=March 31, 2012 }} ===Ministry of Education=== The [[Ministry of Education, Culture, and Science (Mongolia)|Ministry of Education]] has recently reformed its laws. In 2000, due to budget deficiencies, Mongolian schools were reported to have resorted to child labour to generate income.'' Decentralization and Recentralization Reform in Mongolia: Tracing the Swing of the Pendulum '' These problems were finally addressed by the 2002 Education Law, in which the government finally recentralised educational finance in the form of the 'single treasury' measure. ===Ministry of Justice and Home Affairs=== Police laws were adopted in 1994 and were implemented to UN standards. The Code of Conduct for Law Enforcement Officials and the Basic Principles for the Use of Force and Firearms by Law Enforcement Officials are the body of regulations governing all law enforcement officers.[http://www.uncjin.org/Standards/Conduct/ccl/mongolia.pdf " Application of the Code of Conduct for Law Enforcement Officials"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113093745/http://www.uncjin.org/Standards/Conduct/ccl/mongolia.pdf |date=January 13, 2012 }} ===National Human Rights Commission=== The National Human Rights Commission of Mongolia Act was enacted to empower and regulate the administrative functions of the National Human Rights Commission. Thereafter, the Commission was established by a [[State Great Khural]] resolution on 11 January 2001.[http://www.mn-nhrc.org/en/about "About the National Human Rights Commission of Mongolia Act"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110902212633/http://www.mn-nhrc.org/en/about |date=September 2, 2011 }} The Act empowers the Commission with the power to investigate complaints with regards to violations of human rights,[http://www.hurights.or.jp/archives/database/nhri-law-mongolia.html "National Human Rights Commission of Mongolia Act"] amongst others. ==Process of regulatory rulemaking and discretion of regulators== {{Main|Rulemaking}} [[File:President Putin meeting deputies of the Great State Hural-1.jpg|thumb|left| [[State Great Khural]]]] ===Legislature's role=== The 1992 [[Constitution of Mongolia]] introduced a parliamentary system. Laws are made by a unicameral legislature known as the [[State Great Khural]] comprising 76 members representing 26 multi-member constituencies who are elected by bloc vote for a term of 4 years. External input is sought by the legislature to ensure greater inclusiveness in decision-making. [[ngo|Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)]] and [[Community organization|Community-Based Organizations (CBOs)]] can participate in the law-making process by joining a group to aid in the drafting of a specific law, or by special invitation (fairly rare). In 2007, a CBO coalition proposed amendments to the law-making process which have been tabled in Parliament. The ‘citizens’ hall’ process was initiated in 2009 to facilitate the public’s input into the law-making process. These efforts also extend to ensuring transparency in executive action. In 2009, a parliamentary working group on the mineral sector was set up in an effort to ensure that Mongolia does not repeat the mistakes of other resource-rich countries in its mining program and that expansion of the mining sector adheres to principles of transparency."Mongolia Mission Report – Parliamentary Network on World Bank" [[File:Sükhbaataryn Batbold (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|200x200px|[[Prime Minister of Mongolia]]]] ===Executive's role=== The Executive comprises the [[Prime Minister of Mongolia|Prime Minister]] and his Cabinet, appointed by the [[President of Mongolia|President]], a ceremonial head of state. The Executive enforces the laws made by the [[State Great Khural|Legislature]] and can create subsidiary legislation to that end. The Executive too has taken steps to ensure transparency. Mongolia’s National Legal Institute (NLI), which is affiliated with the Ministry of Home Affairs and Justice, makes all approved legislation available online. The NLI also inputs into the legislative process by researching existing and proposed laws and by introducing new laws to the general public. The NLI also cooperates with the [[State Great Khural|Mongolian parliament]] by exchanging information directly with the parliamentary research center. This ensures that citizens are aware of the laws they are subjected to and reflects transparency of rule-making to the Mongolian public. Executive action in Mongolia is also bound by international conventions to which it is a signatory. This is stipulated in Article 10(3) of the [[Constitution of Mongolia|Mongolian Constitution]]. 160 out of the 373 laws in force in [[Mongolia]] included provisions stating that should they conflict with international treaties, the treaties will take precedence."Mongolia Laws-Child Rights Information Network" Executive power can also be subjected to [[judicial review]], as will be discussed below. ==Process for private challenges to government actions and rules== {{Main|Judicial Review}} [[File:9 steps.jpg|thumb|right|Process of judicial review.]] ===Judicial review of administrative action=== Individuals may challenge [[Executive (government)|executive]] acts through a process known as [[judicial review]]. ====Case Study==== In one example of an action involving judicial review of administrative action in 2005,"Decision of the Administrative Court,Arkhangai Province,No.4 (May 2, 2005) (Jargalsaikhan J)" an application for a mining license by a mining company was discussed at a local ''hural'' (legislature) of a [[Sum (country subdivision)#Mongolia|''soum'']] (district)"A governmental sub-division of Mongolia with administrative powers" and most of those present were opposed to the application. However, the Praesidium (executive head of the ''soum'') approved of the application and the mining company then obtained a license from the central government. Despite protests from leaders of the ''hural'', the Praesidium issued a decision that the company had the right to proceed under its license. The leaders of the ''hural'' subsequently appealed to the Arkhangai Province Administrative Court. The court held that: *the Praesidium had no authority to overrule the hural; *the mining company's license was invalid; *if the river were damaged by mining activities, the families in the valley would not be able to sustain their herds and would have to move to the city; and *it called for more transparency in licensing procedures by the ''soum'' executive. ====Process of judicial review==== Step 1: A complainant must submit his complaint against a government action within 30 days under the statute of limitation. {{Citation | last1 = Tsend | first1 = Tsogt | title = Judicial Procedure for Administrative Case in Mongolia | year = 2010 | publisher = Social Science Research Network | pages = | isbn = | ssrn = 1695283 }} (one-click download available for pdf; File name: SSRN-id1695283. ; Size: 128K) Step 2: A pre-hearing is conducted by the Administrative Tribunal before the complaint is allowed to proceed to the administrative courts. At the hearing, a direct supervising officer decides on the legality of the government action. Step 3: Parties not in favour of the outcome of the pre-hearing are allowed to file an appeal to the administrative courts. Step 4: The administrative courts are to allow commencement of the action within 7 days upon receiving the claim. Step 5: A court official delivers the summons to the defendant. Step 6: In court, the judge or his law clerk would submit the copy of claim, attached materials, and inform the defendant of his rights. Step 7: When a claim is accepted by the court, the judge invites the defendant to a meeting to determine whether there is a valid defense. If a settlement is not reached, a date is allocated for the hearing and it must be held within 75 days (for the Capital City Administrative Court) or 85 days (for provincial administrative courts) after filing. Step 8: A public trial is held. All evidence is presented and examined at the hearing and the court secretary makes a full transcript. Step 9: Decisions are made in the “conference room” after hearing the opinion/comment of the citizen representatives. If there is more than one judge on the bench, the decision is made by majority vote. ==Analysis and assessment of current rules== [[File:Jacku.jpg|thumb|left|Court Structure of Mongolia]] [[File:Papapa.jpg|thumb|left|Divisions of the Supreme Court]] ===Current standard of administrative laws=== Administrative laws in [[Mongolia]] have acceptable standards of transparency and clarity, with 160 of the 373 laws in [[Mongolia]] being international laws incorporated through the signing of treaties.[http://www.crin.org/resources/infoDetail.asp?ID=25088&flag=report "Child Rights Information Network"] For example, most of [[Mongolia|Mongolia’s]] police law (especially the regulations governing the use of force and firearms) adheres to specific UN standards.{{cite web|url=http://www.uncjin.org/Standards/Conduct/ccl/mongolia.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-09-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120113093745/http://www.uncjin.org/Standards/Conduct/ccl/mongolia.pdf |archivedate=2012-01-13 |df= }} For local laws, the Executive has also taken steps to ensure transparency in the rule-making process. However, the transplantation of international standards into the local social climate is insufficient in eradicating unlawful executive behaviour. For example, the detection and prosecution of corrupt police officers remains unsatisfactory due to the lack of an open procedural reporting system within the police force. In addition, the detention and prison system in [[Mongolia]] faces a huge lack of financial resources, giving rise to low inmate living conditions that are incompatible with the law.[http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R41867.pdf"Susan V. Lawrence, "Mongolia: Issues for Congress" (14 June 2011)"] It can thus be seen that though the letter of administrative law is fundamentally sound, its enforcement needs to be strengthened. ===State of judicial review=== The establishment of [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] signified a marked progress in the judicial system of Mongolia as well as the increasing emphasis that the country is placing on protecting [[individual rights]] against unlawful governmental action. Nevertheless, the nascent development of administrative law in [[Mongolia]] has naturally invited a fair share of controversy and criticism over the role of the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] in [[judicial review]]. ====Executive non-compliance with judicial decisions==== In a study conducted by Brent T. WhiteAssociate Professor of Law, University of Arizona, James E. Rogers College of Law in his article,"Rotten to the Core: Project Capture and the Failure of Judicial Reform in Mongolia" [2009] 4 East Asia Law Review 209 50% of experts surveyed disagreed with the statement, “Court decisions are respected and enforced by other branches of government.” These experts also indicated that the executive branch often does not honour court decisions with which it disagrees. One expert even indicated that tax inspectors feel free to ignore decisions by the courts when they believe the courts’ interpretation to be wrong.Interview with Tsogt Natsagdorj, Partner, Bona Lex Law Firm, Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia (May 7, 2008) ====Executive interference with the judiciary==== In the same study, only 19% of the experts surveyed agreed that “Court decisions are free from political influence from other branches of government or public officials.” These experts shared the views that high-ranking government officials, including the [[President of Mongolia|President]], exert considerable influence over the courts, especially where the personal, political or business interests of the governments are at stake. ====Conflicts with the Constitutional ''Tsets''(Court)==== A recent conflict between the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] and the [[Constitutional Court of Mongolia|Constitutional ''Tsets'']] arose in 2004-2005 when the Capital City Administrative Court ruled in favour of the plaintiffs in two landmark cases.''Erdenebat & Erdenebaatar v. Government of Mongolia'' (Capital City Admin. Ct 2005); ''Enkhbold v. General Election Committee'' (Capital City Admin. Ct 2004) An action was then filed in the [[Constitutional Court of Mongolia|Constitutional ''Tsets'']] asserting the [[Constitutionality|unconstitutionality]] of Article 4.1.1 of the Law on Administrative Procedure, which lists the government offices and ministries which may be named as defendants in an [[Judicial review#Judicial review of administrative acts|administrative action]]. In ''Enkhbayar v Parliament'',Constitutional ''Tsets'' (2005) the ''Tsets'' found Article 4.1.1 to be unconstitutional and accordingly directed [[State Great Khural|Parliament]] to amend the Law on Administrative Procedure. Such an incident exemplifies the tension in the duty of the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] in controlling the acts of the Executive and the [[Constitutional Court of Mongolia|Constitutional ''Tsets'']] in protecting the [[Constitution of Mongolia|Constitution]] as the supreme law of the land. In a written article, Tsogt Tsend, presently a Chief Judge in the Administrative Court of Appeals has nonetheless expressed two reasons for underscoring his support of the setting up of separate [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] despite the concern of jurisdictional overlapping with the [[Constitutional Court of Mongolia|Constitutional ''Tsets'']]. The first is the specialized nature of the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] which serves as a focal point for the development of Mongolian administrative law. The second is aggrieved claimants being given provision of access to judges highly trained in the field of administrative law. This will hopefully increase public confidence in the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] and encourage [[Lawyer|attorneys]] to take the fight against illegal administrative action to a new level. ===Comparison with other countries=== Like most [[Civil law (legal system)|civil law systems]], such as [[Kazakhstan]] and [[Law of Germany|Germany]], [[Mongolia]] has specialized [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] with exclusive power to hear [[judicial review]]s. In contrast, in [[common law|common-law]] countries like [[England]] and [[administrative law in Singapore|Singapore]], [[judicial review]] actions are heard in a [[court]] of [[general jurisdiction]] like the [[High Court]]. {{Citation | last1 = Nelken | first1 = David | last2 = Orucu | first2 = Esin | title = Comparative Law: A Handbook | year = 2007 | publisher = Hart Publishing | pages = | isbn = 978-1-84113-596-0 | url = https://www.amazon.com/Comparative-Law-Handbook-David-Nelken/dp/1841135968/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1317203008&sr=1-3 | accessdate = 2011-09-28 }} In addition, the powers of the [[Administrative courts in Mongolia|administrative courts]] are derived from a codified statute called the Law on Administrative Procedure. This ensures certainty, reliability and legitimacy. In [[common law]] courts, (e.g. in [[England]]) [[judicial review]] is developed through [[case law]] and is not a power granted by [[statute]], a result of which people have [[Judicial interference|questioned the legitimacy of this process]]. ==See also== *[[United States administrative law]] *[[Administrative law in the People's Republic of China]] *[[Administrative law]] *[[Canadian administrative law]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.nyulawglobal.org/globalex/mongolia.htm The Mongolian Legal System and Laws: a Brief Overview ] *[http://www.lexadin.nl/wlg/legis/nofr/oeur/lxwemon.htm Legislation Mongolia] {{Law}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Administrative Law}} [[Category:Administrative law by country|Mongolia]] [[Category:Mongolian law]] [[Category:Politics of Mongolia]]

page.title: Barclays Bank Ltd v W J Simms, Son and Cooke (Southern) Ltd

revision.comment: [[[[Category:Barclays litigation|W J Simms]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Use British English|date=April 2016}}
{{Infobox court case |name = Barclays Bank Ltd v W J Simms, Son and Cooke (Southern) Ltd |court = [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] |image = Barclays Wealth Guernsey.jpg |imagesize = 200 |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = Barclays Bank Ltd v (1) W J Simms, Son and Cooke (Southern) Ltd and (2) William Sowman |date decided = {{date|1979-04-24}} |citations = [1980] 1 QB 677, [1979] 3 All ER 522 |transcripts = |judges = [[Robert Goff, Baron Goff of Chieveley|Robert Goff J]] |number of judges = |decision by = |concurring = |dissenting = |concur/dissent = |prior actions = |appealed from = |appealed to = |subsequent actions = |related actions = |opinions = |keywords = mistake, restitution, breach of mandate |italic title = }}
'''''Barclays Bank Ltd v W J Simms, Son and Cooke (Southern) Ltd''''' [1980] 1 QB 677, [1979] 3 All ER 522 was a decision of the [[High Court of Justice]] relating to the recovery of a payment mistakenly made by a bank after the customer had countermanded the [[cheque]].<ref name=Swarb>{{cite web|url=http://swarb.co.uk/barclays-bank-v-wj-simms-cooke-southern-ltd-qbd-1979/|title=Barclays Bank -v- WJ Simms & Cooke (Southern) Ltd; QBD 1979|publisher=swarb.co.uk|accessdate=25 April 2016}}</ref>
The decision is important not only for the specific point in issue, but it also was one of the earlier cases in relation to the modern development of the [[Restitution in English law|English law of restitution]] in relation to payments made under [[English unjust enrichment law#Mistake|mistake of fact]] and the defence of [[change of position]]. One commentator has gone so far as to say: "the decision of Robert Goff J in ''Barclays Bank v Simms'' should be considered to be the ''[[Donoghue v Stevenson]]'' of restitution for mistake."<ref name=Virgo />
==Facts== The Royal British Legion Housing Association Ltd (called the "Association" in the judgment) was a customer of [[Barclays Bank]]. The Association had entered into a standard form building contract with W J Simms (called the "Company" in the judgment) for building works in the amount of just over ₤699,000. Separately the Company had obtained a bank loan from [[National Westminster Bank]] pursuant to which the Company had granted National Westminster Bank an all-assets [[floating charge]].
On 12 September 1977 the Association issued a cheque for ₤24,000 to the Company upon completion of certain works as specified in the contract. However, on the next day - 13 September 1977 - National Westminster Bank appointed a [[Receivership|receiver]] over the Company's assets and undertaking. Under clause 25 of the building contract the appointment of a receiver terminated the contract (albeit with an option to renew).
On the 15 September 1977 at 9.20am, after they had heard that the Company had gone into receivership, the Association contacted the bank and instructed the bank to put a stop on the cheque. Those instructions were confirmed in writing, and entered by Barclays Bank in its computer system. However, due to an error the payment was made. Once the bank discovered the error, they contacted the receiver and demanded repayment of the sum, but the receiver (Mr Sowman) refused. The bank accepted that it was not entitled to debit the account of the Association, and brought proceedings against the Company for the return of the monies which it had mistakenly paid out under the stopped cheque.
==Judgment==
===Mistake of fact=== In a long and difficult judgment, [[Robert Goff, Baron Goff of Chieveley|Robert Goff J]] analysed and tried to rationalise a swathe of existing case law in relation to payments made under mistake of fact, starting with ''[[Kelly v Solari]]'' (1841) 9 M&W 54. After summarising the relevant cases, and noting which ones appeared to be inconsistent with House of Lords authority, the judge summarised the position as follows:
{{Cquote|(1) If a person pays money to another under a mistake of fact which causes him to make the payment, he is prima facie entitled to recover it as money paid under a mistake of fact. (2) His claim may however fail if (a) the payer intends that the payee shall have the money at all events, whether the fact be true or false, or is deemed in law so to intend; or (b) the payment is made for good consideration, in particular if the money is paid to discharge and does discharge a debt owed to the payee (or a principal on whose behalf he is authorised to receive the payment) by the payer or by a third party by whom he is authorised to discharge the debt; or (c) the payee has changed his position in good faith or is deemed in law to have done so.<ref>[1980] QB 677 at 695C</ref>}}
Robert Goff J stated that these principles were derived from the speeches in the three [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]] cases which he had reviewed. Unusually, he also stated a number of propositions which had been previously enunciated in cases which he determined were ''not'' correct when taking against the authorities as a whole.<ref>[1980] QB 677 at 696B-C</ref>
He also noted that if the payment had been made by the bank under a [[contract]] then there could be no recovery unless the contract itself was [[void (law)|void]] for mistake. However, in this case there was no contract between Barclays and W J Simms - only a putative mandate from their customer to pay money over.
===Mandate=== Robert Goff J noted that a bank which pays a cheque drawn or purportedly drawn by a customer without a mandate is paying without mandate, and cannot debit the customer's account. In such cases, the bank has paid out its own money. However, the bank is entitled to recover the mistaken payment unless the payee has changed his position in good faith. But if the payment had been within the customer's mandate (i.e. the mistake of fact had been related to something else entirely) there could be no recovery, as the payment would discharge the customer's debt to the payee.
===Change of position=== The judge then reviewed the various cases suggesting that where a payee has changed their position in good faith in reliance upon the payment, they should not be required to repay sums where it would be inequitable to do so. Noting a number of technical rules which had evolved in the judgments, Robert Goff J confined himself to saying "if, in due course, full recognition is given to the defence of change of position, there will be no further need for any such stringent rule and the law can be reformulated on a more rational and less technical basis."<ref>[1980] QB 677 at 703B. As the judge predicted, the defence was in due course recognised by the House of Lords in {{cite BAILII|litigants=[[Lipkin Gorman v Karpnale Ltd]]|court=UKHL | year=1988 |num=12 |date={{date|1991-06-06}}}}, where Robert Goff was also sitting and gave the lead judgment.</ref>
===Decision=== Applying the facts to the case, the court held that (1) the mistake of the bank in overlooking the instruction to stop the cheque caused the payment; that (2) as the bank was acting without mandate, no obligation of the Association to the payee was discharge, and it follows from this that the payee gave no consideration to the bank for payment; (3) there was no evidence of any change of position by the recipient. Accordingly, the court ordered that the sums be repaid to the bank.
The judge stated "I must confess I am happy to be able to reach the conclusion that the money is recoverable by the plaintiff bank."<ref>[1980] QB 677 at 703F</ref> There was a bona fide dispute between the Association and the Company as to whether the termination of the building contract terminated the right to the interim payment. Now that dispute could be litigated. Had the payment remained with the bank it would have been swallowed up by the creditors of the insolvent company leaving Barclays Bank to claim for a mere dividend in the bankruptcy, unjust enriching the creditors of the insolvent Company.
==Commentary== {{Clist mistakes}} The decision was not subject to an appeal, but it has been consistently applied since it was handed down and has not been subject to judicial criticism or doubted. It has been cited and applied frequently<ref name=Swarb /> including by the House of Lords in {{cite BAILII|litigants=[[Lipkin Gorman v Karpnale Ltd]]|court=UKHL |year=1988 |num=12 |date={{date|1991-06-06}}}} and the [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council|Privy Council]] in {{cite BAILII|litigants=[[Dextra Bank & Trust Company Limited v Bank of Jamaica]] |court=UKPC |year=2002 |num=50 |date={{date|2001-11-26}}}}. One academic commentator has said "the decision of Robert Goff J in ''Barclays Bank v Simms'' should be considered to be the ''[[Donoghue v Stevenson]]'' of restitution for mistake."<ref name=Virgo>{{cite book|last1=Virgo |first1=Graham |author-link1=Graham Virgo |year=1999 |title=The Principles of the Law of Restitution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bpQC6F46urIC&pg=PA158&lpg=PA158&dq=importance+of+barclays+bank+v+simms&source=bl&ots=ImAJYzeyW5&sig=Bfd03jnXKhpWT-4sDY7fzFwG_aA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjaxqGs0arMAhXTsh4KHWvXCREQ6AEIPjAF#v=onepage&q=importance%20of%20barclays%20bank%20v%20simms&f=false|publisher=[[Clarendon Press]]|isbn=0-19-876377-8|page=158}}</ref>
The decision was also subject to limited academic criticism, including a strongly worded article by Professor [[Roy Goode]] in the [[Law Quarterly Review]].<ref>[[Roy Goode|Goode, R.M.]] "''The bank's right to recover money paid on a stopped cheque''" (1981) 97 LQR 254</ref> Goode argued that the case was wrongly decided for three reasons: first, although the bank lacked express authority to pay on the cheque, it had [[implied authority]]; secondly, that the payee had changed their position and so should have had a good defence in law; and thirdly (although slightly speculatively) the better solution would be to treat the payment as discharging the debt of the customer and for the bank to be able to reclaim the sums from the customer under the doctrine of [[subrogation]]. Goode's criticisms of the decision have not been broadly accepted, either by commentators on the law of restitution,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Goff |first1=Robert |author-link1=Robert Goff, Baron Goff of Chieveley |last2=Jones |first2=Gareth |author-link2=Gareth Jones (lawyer) |year=2007 |title=[[Goff & Jones|The Law of Restitution]] |edition=7th |publisher=[[Sweet & Maxwell]] |at=4-032 |isbn=9780421926004 |quote=Professor Goode also argues that Barclays had the apparent authority of the drawer to make the payment so that the payment was effect to discharge the drawer's liability on the cheque. We know of no case in which this argument has been advanced; and we doubt whether it can be right that the drawer held out the bank as having authority to make the payment so as to preclude him from asserting that the bank did not have authority to do so: see ''Freeman & Lockyer v Buckhurst Park Properties (Mangal) Ltd'' [1964] 2 QB 480.}}</ref> or on banking law.<ref>{{cite book |author1=E.P. Ellinger |author2=E. Lomnicka |author3=C. Hare |year=2011|title=Ellinger's Modern Banking Law |edition=5th|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=978-019-923209-3|page=536|quote=This criticism appears to be misplaced. Such an argument was firmly rejected by the Court of Appeal in ''[[Lloyds Bank plc v Independent Insurance Co Ltd]]'', on the grounds that, first, there was no holding out that the bank had authority to make the payment, and, secondly, there was no reliance by the payee on the bank having authority to pay.}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Lloyds Bank plc v Independent Insurance Co Ltd]]'' [2000] 1 QB 110

GlaxoSmithKline Inc. |heard-date=13 January 2012 |decided-date=18 October 2012 |citations= 2012 SCC 52 |docket= 33874 |history=Appeal from {{cite CanLII|litigants=GlaxoSmithKline Inc. v. Canada|link=|year=2010|source=fca|num=201|pinpoint=|parallelcite=2010 DTC 7053|date=2010-07-26|courtname=|juris=}}, setting aside {{cite CanLII|litigants=GlaxoSmithKline Inc. v. The Queen|link=|year=2008|source=tcc|num=324|pinpoint=|parallelcite=2008 DTC 3957|date=2008-05-30|courtname=|juris=}} |subsequent= |ruling= Appeal and cross-appeal dismissed. |ratio= Under ITA s. 69(2), the price established in a non-arm's length transfer pricing transaction is to be redetermined as if it were between parties dealing at [[arm's length principle|arm's length]], and such an exercise may take into account transactions other than the purchasing transactions. |chief-justice= [[Beverley McLachlin|McLachlin CJ]] |puisne-justices= [[Marie Deschamps|Deschamps]], [[Rosalie Abella|Abella]], [[Marshall Rothstein|Rothstein]], [[Thomas Cromwell (jurist)|Cromwell]], [[Michael Moldaver|Moldaver]] and [[Andromache Karakatsanis|Karakatsanis]] JJ |Unanimous= [[Marshall Rothstein|Rothstein J]] |Majority= |JoinMajority= |Concurrence= |JoinConcurrence= |Concurrence/Dissent= |JoinConcurrence/Dissent= |Dissent= |JoinDissent= |NotParticipating= |LawsApplied= [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-3.3/index.html ''Income Tax Act'' (Canada)] }} '''''Canada v GlaxoSmithKline Inc'''''<ref>{{lexum-scc|2012|52}}</ref> is the first ruling of the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] that deals with issues involving [[transfer pricing]] and how they are treated under the ''Income Tax Act'' of Canada ("ITA").
==Background== [[File:Ranitidine-A-3D-balls.png|thumb|left|Molecular structure of [[ranitidine]]]] In 1976, a predecessor of [[GlaxoSmithKline]] Inc. ("GSK") discovered the drug [[ranitidine]], which was approved for sale in Canada in 1981 and marketed as Zantac. Ranitidine's primary manufacture was conducted by related companies located in the United Kingdom and Singapore, and it was subsequently sold to Adechsa SA, another related company located in Switzerland, for further sale to other group companies and unrelated distributors at prices dictated by the parent company.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 9{{endash}}11</ref>
In addition, the following intercompany agreements were entered into by Glaxo Canada:
:* in 1972, a Consultancy Agreement with Glaxo Group Limited covering services and intangibles provided to Glaxo Canada in exchange for a 5% royalty<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 8</ref> :* in 1983, a Supply Agreement with Adechsa for the purchase of ranitidine<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 12</ref> :* an amendment to the 1972 agreement, to cover services and intangibles relating to Zantac<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 14</ref> :* in 1988, a Licence Agreement with Glaxo Group Limited that replaced the 1972 agreement, and which covered various services and intangibles, in exchange for a 6% royalty on the net sales of drugs<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 15</ref>
During its taxation years from 1990 to 1993, Glaxo deducted and remitted [[withholding tax]] with respect to royalty payments it made to Glaxo Group Limited under the 1988 agreement, but not with respect to payments to Adechsa under the 1983 agreement, which were considered fully deductible as [[cost of goods sold]].<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 17</ref>
By 1990, [[generic drug]] manufacturers such as [[Apotex]] and [[Novopharm]] were able to acquire ranitidine on the open market at prices significantly less than Glaxo Canada was paying under its 1983 agreement.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, para 19</ref> The [[Minister of National Revenue]] subsequently reassessed Glaxo Canada's 1990{{endash}}1993 taxation years under:
:* s. 69(2),<ref>replaced in 1998 by the current [http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-3.3/page-393.html#h-150 ITA s. 247(2)(a) and (c)]</ref> which applied where a taxpayer is not dealing at arm's length with a non-resident and pays an amount greater than the amount "that would have been reasonable in the circumstances if the non-resident person and the taxpayer had been dealing at arm's length". In such a case, the transfer price is deemed to be the reasonable amount determined on an arm's length basis.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 20</ref> :* s. 56(2),<ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-3.3/page-62.html#h-18 ITA s. 56(2)]</ref> which resulted in a deemed dividend to Adechsa, and its assessment for withholding tax under Part XIII of the ''ITA''.
Glaxo Canada subsequently appealed the reassessments to the [[Tax Court of Canada]].
==The courts below==
===Tax Court of Canada=== On 30 May 2008, the TCC allowed the appeals, ordering the s. 69(2) and Part XIII assessments to be returned to the Minister for reassessment with respect to a minor pricing adjustment. Otherwise, the approach used in arriving at the assessments was considered to be correct. [[Gerald J. Rip|Rip ACJ]] (as he then was) identified the key issues in the case as:<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (TCC), par. 70</ref>
#whether the Supply Agreement and the Licence Agreement should be considered together to determine a reasonable transfer price #the meaning of the phrase "reasonable in the circumstances" in s. 69(2) #the impact of the differences in Glaxo's [[good manufacturing practice]]s and [[Occupational safety and health|health, safety and environmental standard]]s on the comparability of the ranitidine purchased by the appellant with that purchased by the generic companies
He ruled that the [[Transfer pricing#Comparable uncontrolled price|comparable uncontrolled price]] method was the preferred approach to use to establish the arm's length transfer price, subject to adjustment for the issues in dispute.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (TCC), par. 71</ref> He also ruled that the Part XIII assessments for withholding tax were essentially correct, but subject to a minor pricing adjustment with respect to the drug's granulation.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (TCC), par. 176</ref>
===Federal Court of Appeal=== The TCC ruling was set aside by the [[Federal Court of Appeal (Canada)|Federal Court of Appeal]] on 26 July 2010. In his ruling, [[Marc Nadon|Nadon JA]] stated the trial judge had erred in the following respects:
:* concluding that the Licence Agreement and Supply Agreement were to be considered independently of one another within the context of ''Singleton v. Canada''<ref>''Singleton v. Canada'', 2001 SCC 61, [2001] 2 SCR 1046 {{lexum-scc|2001|61}}</ref><ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (FCA), par. 65</ref> :* misunderstanding the s. 69(2) test of what is "reasonable in the circumstances"<ref name = "par69">''GlaxoSmithKline'' (FCA), par. 69</ref>
The ''Singleton'' test applied to a different part of the Act under different circumstances,<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (FCA), para 66{{endash}}68</ref> and the consideration of what is reasonable must be governed by the standard noted in ''Gabco Ltd v Minister of National Revenue'',<ref>''Gabco Ltd v Minister of National Revenue'', 68 DTC 5210 (Ex Cr), as endorsed by the FCA in {{cite CanLII|litigants=Petro-Canada v. The Queen|link=|year=2004|source=fca|num=158|pinpoint=|parallelcite=58 DTC 6329, [2004] 3 CTC 156|date=2004-04-23|courtname=|juris=}}</ref> where Cattanach J stated:
{{quote|It is not a question of the Minister or this Court substituting its judgment for what is a reasonable amount to pay, but rather a case of the Minister or the Court coming to the conclusion that no reasonable business man would have contracted to pay such an amount having only the business considerations of the appellant in mind.<ref name = "par69" />}}
[[File:price trans-comp ext-small.jpg|thumb|175px|Transfer Pricing with a Competitive External Market]] Nadon JA subsequently listed the following "circumstances" of what could be considered as reasonable in the case at bar:<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (FCA), par. 79</ref>
#Glaxo Group owned the Zantac trademark and would own it even if the appellant was an arm's length licensee. #Zantac commanded a premium over generic ranitidine drugs. #Glaxo Group owned the ranitidine patent and would have owned it even if the appellant had been in an arm's length relationship. #Without the License Agreement, the appellant would not have been in a position to use the ranitidine patent and the Zantac trademark.
Consequently, in those circumstances, the only possibility open to the appellant would have been to enter the generic market where the cost of entry into that market would likely have been high, considering that both Apotex and Novopharm were already well placed and positioned. Without the License Agreement, the appellant would not have had access to the portfolio of other patented and trademarked products to which it had access under the License Agreement.
The appeal was allowed with costs, setting aside the Tax Court's decision, and the matter was returned to the trial judge for rehearing and reconsideration of the matter in the light of the FCA's reasons.
An appeal by the Crown on the reversal, and cross-appeal by GSK with respect to the case being returned to the TCC for rehearing, were subsequently made to the [[Supreme Court of Canada]], which heard the case on 13 January 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Julius Melnitzer|title = The Queen v. GlaxoSmithKline: SCC reserves on critical transfer pricing appeal|url = http://business.financialpost.com/2012/01/13/the-queen-v-glaxosmithkline-scc-reserves-on-critical-transfer-pricing-appeal/|publisher = ''[[Financial Post]]''|date = 2012-01-13|accessdate = 2012-10-17}}</ref><ref>[http://www.scc-csc.gc.ca/case-dossier/cms-sgd/webcast-webdiffusion-eng.aspx?33874 Webcast of SCC hearing]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Arguments before the SCC==
===Appeal===
The Crown argued that applying a "reasonable in the circumstances" test, as the FCA did, does not fulfil the conditions of section 69(2), as a price that may be reasonable is not necessarily an arm's-length price.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 30{{endash}}34</ref> According to the Crown, only those circumstances that would be relevant to parties bargaining at arm‟s length for a particular good should be considered in the analysis,<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 35{{endash}}49</ref> which it asserted was supported by the SCC's rulings in ''Singleton'' and ''Shell Canada Ltd. v. Canada''.<ref>''Shell Canada Ltd. v. Canada'', [1999] 3 SCR 622, 1999 CanLII 647 (SCC) {{lexum-scc2|1999|3|622|647}}</ref> In its view, other circumstances, such as Glaxo Canada‟s status as a distributor of Zantac, were irrelevant to the consideration of the price paid for ranitidine.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 50{{endash}}92</ref>
In response to questions from the Justices about the meaning of "reasonable circumstances" in s. 69(2), the Crown submitted that:
:* the phrase was intended to consider only the "economically relevant circumstances" pertaining to the specific transaction in question, in accordance with the ''[[OECD]] Transfer Pricing Guidelines''<ref>for current version, see {{Cite web|title = Transfer Pricing Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises and Tax Administrations|url = http://www.oecd.org/ctp/transferpricing/transferpricingguidelinesformultinationalenterprisesandtaxadministrations.htm|publisher = [[OECD]]|accessdate = 2012-10-17}}</ref> :* s. 69(2) did not allow consideration of "the whole deal"
As to questions as to whether a hypothetical independent licensee entering into a similar arrangement with Glaxo could be reassessed in the same manner, the Crown responded that such a licensee could be reassessed as not "dealing at arm‟s length" if it was tied into a set price and had no ability to bargain.
In its submission, GSK concurred with the FCA ruling with respect to the inclusion of the License Agreement in determining reasonable circumstances.<ref>Respondent's factum at SCC, par. 41{{endash}}44</ref> S. 69(2) should therefore be presumed to situate the parties at arm's length, ultimately asking, "Would they do the deal?"<ref>Respondent's factum at SCC, par. 45{{endash}}60</ref> As to questions posed on whether the price paid for ranitidine was a bundled price for tangible and intangible property{{emdash}}thus potentially triggering liability for withholding tax{{emdash}}GSK contended that the situation was analogous to luxury brands such as [[Rolex]] and [[Porsche]]. While there are undoubtedly components of intellectual property embedded in the price of the tangible good, it is not Canadian law or practice to segregate and separately tax the discrete elements.
As to the applicability of the [[OECD]] guidelines, GSK stated that there was no dispute between the parties that the issue in question is solely the price of the tangible good rather than its characterization.<ref>Respondent's factum at SCC, par. 90{{endash}}99</ref>
===Cross-appeal===
In its cross-appeal, GSK submitted that it had demolished the Minister's reassessment by demonstrating that the theory at the heart of the liability determined by the Minister was wrong, and therefore the reassessment must be set aside.<ref>Respondent's factum at SCC, par. 100{{endash}}125</ref> To a question posed as to whether the onus was still on the taxpayer to prove that it did not overpay for ranitidine (as the lower courts had not yet addressed the issue), GSK responded that, once it had demolished the Crown's basis for reassessment, the onus shifted to the Crown to show that Glaxo had paid too much.
In reply, the Crown contended that GSK did not demolish the reassessment, and therefore it remained valid and open for reconsideration by the TCC.<ref>Appellant's factum at SCC, par. 100{{endash}}109</ref> To the question of whether, if the case were to be sent back to the TCC, any other issue could be argued, the Crown stated that the argument would remain essentially the same, as the generic comparable prices comprised the only available information to support arm's-length prices for ranitidine.
==Decision by the SCC== [[File:ON-CourSupreme 20090606-164356 panoramique.jpg|thumb|left|Panoramic view of [[Supreme Court of Canada]] audience chamber]] In a unanimous decision by [[Marshall Rothstein|Rothstein J]], the appeal and cross-appeal were dismissed.
===Appeal===
While s. 69(2) does not state what is a "reasonable amount", the OECD guidelines do provide commentary and methodology pertaining to the issue of transfer pricing. However, the test of any set of transactions or prices ultimately must be determined according to s. 69(2).<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 20</ref>
:* The trial judge erred in relying on ''Singleton'' and ''Shell Canada'' for requiring a transaction-by-transaction approach, but s. 69(2) only requires that the price established in a non-arm’s length transfer pricing transaction is to be redetermined as if it were between parties dealing at arm’s length. If the circumstances require, transactions other than the purchasing transactions must be taken into account to determine whether the actual price was or was not greater than the amount that would have been reasonable had the parties been dealing at arm’s length.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 38</ref> :* The OECD Guidelines state that a proper application of the arm’s length principle requires that regard be had for the "economically relevant characteristics" of the arm’s length and non-arm’s length circumstances to ensure they are "sufficiently comparable".<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 42</ref> :* Considering the Licence and Supply agreements together offers a realistic picture of the profits of Glaxo Canada. It cannot be irrelevant that Glaxo Canada’s function was primarily as a secondary manufacturer and marketer. It did not originate new products and the intellectual property rights associated with them. Nor did it undertake the investment and risk involved with originating new products. Nor did it have the other risks and investment costs which Glaxo Group undertook under the Licence Agreement. The prices paid by Glaxo Canada to Adechsa were a payment for a bundle of at least some rights and benefits under the Licence Agreement and product under the Supply Agreement.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 52</ref>
It was also noted that the issue as to whether the purchase price includes compensation for intellectual property rights granted to Glaxo Canada had not been specifically argued before the SCC, and could still trigger potential further liability for Part XIII withholding tax. It may still be raised during the subsequent rehearing at the TCC.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 57</ref>
The following further guidance was given with respect to the forthcoming redetermination by the trial judge:<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 61{{endash}}64</ref>
#In determining what constitutes a "reasonable amount" under s. 69(2), even the OECD guidelines concede that "transfer pricing is not an exact science". As long as a transfer price is within what the court determines is a reasonable range, the requirements of the section should be satisfied. #While assessment of the evidence is a matter for the trial judge, the respective roles and functions of Glaxo Canada and the Glaxo Group should be kept in mind. Whether or not compensation for intellectual property rights is justified in this particular case, is a matter for determination by the Tax Court judge. #Prices between parties dealing at arm's length will be established having regard to the independent interests of each party to the transaction, and an appropriate determination under the arm's length test of s. 69(2) should reflect these realities. #In this case there is some evidence that indicates that arm's length distributors have found it in their interest to acquire ranitidine from a Glaxo Group supplier, rather than from generic sources. This suggests that higher-than-generic transfer prices are justified and are not necessarily greater than a reasonable amount under s. 69(2).
===Cross-appeal=== The assessments were based on two assumptions:<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 70</ref>
:* the Appellant paid Adechsa, with whom it was not dealing at arm’s length, a price for ranitidine which was greater than the amount that would have been reasonable in the circumstances if the Appellant and Adechsa had been dealing at arm’s length :* any amounts paid by the appellant to Adechsa over and above the prices paid by other Canadian pharmaceutical companies were not for the supply of ranitidine
Only the second could be characterized as having been demolished, but if Glaxo had been successful in establishing that the prices it paid were reasonable, the first would have been demolished as well. As [[Claire L'Heureux-Dubé|L'Heureux-Dubé]] J had stated in ''Hickman Motors Ltd v Canada'', the taxpayer's burden is to "'demolish' the exact assumptions made by the Minister but no more".<ref>''Hickman Motors Ltd v Canada'', [1997] 2 SCR 336 {{lexum-scc2|1997|2|336|357}}</ref><ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 72</ref>
As Glaxo had previously conceded at the FCA that the court could determine what was the reasonable amount, it was within the FCA's discretion to remit the question to the TCC for that very determination. Accordingly, that aspect of the FCA's ruling was upheld.<ref>''GlaxoSmithKline'' (SCC), par. 76</ref>
==Impact== There has been little jurisprudence on [[transfer pricing]] in Canada, and, being the first time this area had been addressed by the SCC, the judgment was greatly anticipated, not just in Canada,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tax Alert - Canada: Supreme Court of Canada hears the ''GlaxoSmithKline'' case|url = http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/Tax_Alert_2012_No_01/$FILE/TaxAlert2012No01.pdf|publisher = [[Ernst & Young LLP]]|date = 2012-01-16|accessdate = 2012-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = GlaxoSmithKline Transfer Pricing Decision - What's at Stake?|url = http://www.kpmg.com/ca/en/issuesandinsights/articlespublications/global-tax-adviser/pages/glaxosmithkline%20transfer%20pricing%20decision%20-%20what%27s%20at%20stake.aspx|publisher = [[KPMG LLP]]|date = 2012-09-11|accessdate = 2012-10-17}}</ref> but worldwide.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Arm's Length Standard in the Real World: The Federal Court of Appeals Decision in GlaxoSmithKline Inc.|url = http://www.bakermckenzie.com/RRCanadaArmsLengthStandardNov10/|publisher = [[Baker & McKenzie]]|date = November 2010|accessdate = 2012-10-17|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101225005025/http://www.bakermckenzie.com/RRCanadaArmsLengthStandardNov10/#|archive-date = 2010-12-25|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = GlaxoSmithKline Inc v The Queen|url = http://moorestephensresources.com.au/articles/386/1/GlaxoSmithKline-Inc-v-The-Queen/Page1.html|publisher = Moore Stephens|date = 2010-08-11|accessdate = 2012-10-18|archive-url = https://archive.is/20130115011210/http://moorestephensresources.com.au/articles/386/1/GlaxoSmithKline-Inc-v-The-Queen/Page1.html#|archive-date = 2013-01-15|dead-url = yes|df = }}</ref> While many [[tax professional]]s welcomed the SCC endorsement of a "business reality test", others had been expecting more specific guidance.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Drew Hasselback|title = Supreme Court of Canada adopts broad test on transfer pricing|url = http://business.financialpost.com/2012/10/18/supreme-court-of-canada-adopts-broad-test-on-transfer-pricing/|work=[[Financial Post]]|date = 2012-01-18|accessdate = 2012-10-19}}</ref> There was also speculation that the time may be ripe for the Crown and GSK to reach a settlement, rather than spend more time in pursuing a rehearing at the TCC.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tax Alert - Canada: Supreme Court of Canada sends GlaxoSmithKline transfer pricing case back to the Tax Court of Canada|url = http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/Tax_Alert_2012_No_44/$FILE/TaxAlert2012No44.pdf|publisher = [[Ernst & Young LLP]]|date = 2012-10-19|accessdate = 2012-10-19}}</ref> The case was ultimately settled on 12 January 2015, prior to the TCC's rehearing of the matter, with details of the agreement remaining confidential.<ref>{{cite news |author= Julius Melnitzer |title= GlaxoSmithKline transfer pricing case settled|url= http://business.financialpost.com/2015/01/12/glaxosmithkline-transfer-pricing-case-settled/|newspaper= [[Financial Post]]|location= Toronto|date= 12 January 2015}}</ref>
The SCC's statement that an arm's-length price can fall within an acceptable range of prices has also been seen as significant, and consistent with the 2010 OECD transfer pricing guidelines, as it appears to be contrary to the long-standing policy of the [[Canada Revenue Agency]] to express a preference for unweighted yearly averages of comparators’ pricing in such circumstances.<ref>{{Cite web|author = Jonathan Crangle|title = Transfer Pricing: Supreme Court of Canada upholds Federal Court of Appeal in Canada v GlaxoSmithKline Inc.|url = http://www.taxchambers.ca/transfer-pricing-supreme-court-of-canada-upholds-federal-court-of-appeal-in-canada-v-glaxosmithkline-inc/|publisher = Tax Chambers|date = 2012-10-18|accessdate = 2012-10-24}}</ref> In addition, the SCC's guidance to the TCC strongly suggests that Canadian courts must keep an eye on the bigger picture in making their transfer pricing determinations, and the determination of arm's-length pricing is quite distinct from the narrower concept of [[fair market value]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Canada’s Supreme Court Releases First Transfer Pricing Decision in GlaxoSmithKline|url = http://www.osler.com/NewsResources/Canadas-Supreme-Court-Releases-First-Transfer-Pricing-Decision-in-GlaxoSmithKline/|publisher = [[Osler, Hoskin & Harcourt]]|date = 2012-10-19|accessdate = 2012-10-28}}</ref>
When s. 69(2) was reenacted as s. 247(2)(a) and (c) in 1998, the test as to what was reasonable "in the circumstances" was removed. However, it has been contended that the quoted words are implicit in the comparative exercise mandated by the explicit adoption of the arm's-length principle in subsection 247(2),<ref>{{Cite web|author = John J. Tobin|title = Canada’s Top Court Speaks on Transfer Pricing|url = http://www.torys.com/Publications/Pages/TX2012-3_Canadas_Top_Court_Speaks_on_Transfer_Pricing.aspx|publisher = [[Torys LLP]]|date = 2012-10-19|accessdate = 2012-10-21}}</ref> and the [[Tax Court of Canada]] has held that ''GlaxoSmithKline'''s reasoning continues to apply to s. 247 cases.<ref>{{cite CanLII|litigants=McKesson Canada Corporation v. The Queen|link=|year=2013|court=tcc|num=404|format=|pinpoint=par. 121|parallelcite=|date=2013-12-20|courtname=|juris=}}</ref> It should be noted that s. 247 also contains a recharacterization rule at s. 247(2)(b) and (d) that has yet to be assessed in the Canadian courts.<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Bloom|first1= Brian|last2= Vincent|first2= François |year= 2012|title= Respecting the Dualistic Nature of Canada’s Two Transfer Pricing Rules: A Tax Policy and Legal Analysis|journal= Tax Management Transfer Pricing Report|volume= 21|issue= 7|pages= S-3{{endash}}S-20|publisher= |doi= |url= http://www.dwpv.com/~/media/Files/PDF/Article-Transfer-Pricing-Report.ashx|accessdate=2012-10-19}}</ref>
Most recently, it has been argued that the SCC erred in affirming the FCA's application of a reasonable business person test for the purpose of s.69(2), and that the SCC infused additional uncertainty as to which arm's length test applies (i.e., an empirical arm's length test or a reasonable business person test). These errors may require having the court overrule its decision in order to properly consider the Minister's question about the appropriateness of the reasonable business person test.<ref>{{cite journal |author= Amir Pichhadze|year= 2013|title= Canada's Transfer Pricing Test in the Aftermath of GlaxoSmithKline Inc.: A Critique of the Reasonable Business Person Test|journal= International Transfer Pricing Journal|volume= 20|issue= 3|pages= 144{{endash}}162|publisher= |doi= |pmc= |ssrn= 2302606|accessdate=}}</ref>
