fatal fight with Trayvon Martin|publisher=WFTV Orlando|date=June 21, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2012}} Prior to the release of the statements, the only publicly available information about Zimmerman's version of the incident came from interviews with some of his family members and friends and from leaks to the news media by sources inside the investigation and his recorded phone call to 9-1-1. Zimmerman maintained his public silence until he was interviewed by [[Sean Hannity]] of [[Fox News]] on July 18, 2012.{{cite news|title=Exclusive: George Zimmerman breaks silence on 'Hannity'|url=http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/hannity/2012/07/18/exclusive-george-zimmerman-breaks-silence-hannity?intcmp=related|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=July 18, 2012}}{{cite news |url = http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-07-18/news/os-george-zimmerman-sean-hannity-20120718_1_trayvon-martin-george-zimmerman-mark-o-mara|title = George Zimmerman apologizes in interview with Sean Hannity|work = Orlando Sentinel|author1=Stutzman, Rene |author2=Weiner, Jeff |lastauthoramp=yes |date = July 19, 2012|accessdate = July 11, 2013}} According to early news reports on the incident, on the night of the shooting and afterwards, Zimmerman described in detail for investigators what took place.{{cite news |title=EXCLUSIVE: Robert Zimmerman Interview |url=http://www.myfoxorlando.com/story/17376796/exclusive-robert-zimmerman-interview |publisher=WOFL |accessdate=June 21, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604135144/http://www.myfoxorlando.com/story/17376796/exclusive-robert-zimmerman-interview# |archive-date=June 4, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-05-03/news/os-trayvon-martin-circles-george-zimmerman-20120503_1_special-prosecutor-angela-corey-source-police-department Rene Stutzman and Jeff Weiner, "Source: Zimmerman says Trayvon circled his SUV, frightened him"], ''Orlando Sentinel'', May 3, 2012.{{cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-03-26/news/os-trayvon-martin-zimmerman-account-20120326_1_arizona-iced-tea-suv-unarmed-black-teenager|title=Police: Zimmerman says Trayvon decked him with one blow then began hammering his head|work=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=March 26, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-trayvon-martin-case-20120326,0,4845076.story|title=Trayvon Martin case: Martin was the aggressor, police sources say|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=March 26, 2012|first=Rene|last=Lynch|date=March 26, 2012}} Zimmerman said he was driving to the grocery store when he spotted Trayvon Martin walking through the neighborhood. Zimmerman's father said that, while his son was not on duty that night as Neighborhood Watch captain, there had been many break-ins and he thought it suspicious that someone he did not recognize was walking behind the town homes instead of on the street or the sidewalk. Zimmerman therefore called a non-emergency police line to report Martin's behavior and summon police.{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxorlando.com/story/17376796/exclusive-robert-zimmerman-interview|author=Boey, Valerie|title=Exclusive: Robert Zimmerman interview|accessdate=July 11, 2013|publisher=WOFL (Fox 35 Orlando)|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604135144/http://www.myfoxorlando.com/story/17376796/exclusive-robert-zimmerman-interview#|archive-date=June 4, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} Note: Some of the information is from the video, not the text.{{cite news | author= |title = George Zimmerman's dad says Travyon told his son, 'You're gonna die now' | date = March 29, 2012 | publisher = MSNBC | url = http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/03/29/10912176-george-zimmermans-dad-says-travyon-told-his-son-youre-gonna-die-now?lite | accessdate = May 5, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413192224/http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/03/29/10912176-george-zimmermans-dad-says-travyon-told-his-son-youre-gonna-die-now?lite |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 13, 2014}} During the call, Zimmerman told the dispatcher that Martin was "coming to check me out." A source to the ''Orlando Sentinel'' said in May that Zimmerman told investigators that at one point Martin circled his vehicle,{{#tag:ref| An ''Orlando Sentinel'' source reported in May 2012 that Zimmerman told investigators that Martin "was circling" his vehicle at one point, but news stories after Zimmerman's statements to police were released reported that he said Martin "circled" his vehicle.|group = "Note"}} and he rolled up his window to avoid a confrontation. After telling the police dispatcher that Martin "ran",[https://www.motherjones.com/documents/326700-full-transcript-zimmerman "Transcript of George Zimmerman's Call to the Police"], Source: City of Sanford, Florida, published by ''Mother Jones''. Zimmerman left his vehicle on Twin Trees and walked down the sidewalk between Twin Trees and Retreat View Circle to determine his location and ascertain in which direction Martin had fled. The dispatcher asked if Zimmerman was following Martin, and Zimmerman replied "Yeah." Then the dispatcher said, "OK, we don't need you to do that." Zimmerman replied with "OK" and stated that Martin got away. After a discussion about where Zimmerman would meet police, the call ended, and Zimmerman told investigators he was returning to his vehicle after locating an address on Retreat View Circle when Martin approached him from his left rear and confronted him. According to Zimmerman, Martin then punched him in the face, knocking him down, and began beating his head against the sidewalk. Zimmerman said he called out for help while being beaten, and at one point Martin covered his mouth to muffle the screams. According to Zimmerman's father, during the struggle while Martin was on top of Zimmerman, Martin saw the gun Zimmerman was carrying and said something to the effect of "You're gonna die now" or "You're gonna die tonight" and continued to beat Zimmerman. Zimmerman and Martin struggled over the gun, and Zimmerman shot Martin once in the chest at close range. Zimmerman told police he shot Martin in [[self-defense]].{{#tag:ref| Some referenced information is from the embedded video of Robert Zimmerman's interview.|group = "Note"}} On June 21, 2012, Zimmerman's attorneys released audiotapes of several interviews he had with police shortly after the shooting. Also included were Zimmerman's written statement of February 26, 2012, and video recordings of his reenactment of the incident and a voice stress test that he passed.{{cite news |url=http://www.wltz.com/story/18849587/new-zimmerman-material-released|title=New Zimmerman Material Released|publisher=WLTZ|location=Columbus, GA|date=June 21, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/21/justice/florida-teen-shooting/index.html|title=George Zimmerman: Trayvon Martin threatened my life|last=Hayes|first=Ashley|date=June 21, 2012|accessdate=June 21, 2012|publisher=CNN}}{{cite news|title=New audio, video statements released in George Zimmerman case|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/New-evidence-video-released-in-George-Zimmerman-case/-/1637132/15187548/-/np1nkc/-/index.html?treets=orlpn&tml=orlpn_break&ts=T&tmi=orlpn_break_1_06350106212012|publisher=WKMG TV|location=Orlando|accessdate=June 21, 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/06/22/us/21george-zimmerman-transcript.html |title=George Zimmerman's Written Statement|work=The New York Times|date=June 21, 2012 |accessdate=July 4, 2012}} In the interviews, Zimmerman says he took note of Martin because he was near a home that he had previously called police about. He also said "he was just walking casually, not like he was trying to get out of the rain" and he felt "something was off" about Martin.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-06-21/zimmerman-version-of-trayvon-martin-shooting/55748014/1|title=Zimmerman defense releases tapes of his shooting account|last=Bello|first=Marisol|work=USA Today|date=June 21, 2012}} In a reconstruction video-recorded by police the next day, Zimmerman said that after he initially saw Martin on Retreat View Circle he parked his vehicle in front of the club house at the corner of Retreat View Circle and Twin Trees Lane and observed Martin go past him and onto Twin Trees Lane where he lost sight of Martin. He stated the dispatcher asked "can you get to somewhere where you can see him?" and that he then left the club house parking lot and drove onto Twin Trees Lane where he parked. He further stated that at one point Martin circled his truck while he was parked on Twin Trees Lane.{{cite news |author= |url=http://www.wftv.com/videos/news/raw-george-zimmerman-reenacts-trayvon-martin/vcQxd/ |title=Raw: George Zimmerman reenacts Trayvon Martin shooting |publisher=WFTV |date=2012-06-21 |accessdate=2016-07-08}} [[File:Shooting of Trayvon Martin map.png|thumb|upright=2.0|Shooting of Trayvon Martin map]] Zimmerman eventually left his truck and walked down the sidewalk between Twin Trees Lane to Retreat View Circle and gave police an address on Retreat View Circle. He told investigators that he was not following Martin but was "just going in the same direction he was" to find an address, but admitted that he had also left his truck to try to see in which direction Martin had gone. The altercation began, he said, when Martin suddenly appeared while Zimmerman was walking back to his vehicle. He described Martin at different points in the interviews as appearing "out of nowhere", "from the darkness", and as "jump[ing] out of the bushes". Zimmerman said that Martin asked, "You got a fucking problem, homie?" Zimmerman replied no, then Martin said "You got a problem now" and punched Zimmerman.{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Pierre|title=George Zimmerman's Reenactment of Trayvon Martin Shooting|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/george-zimmermans-reenactment-trayvon-martin-shooting/story?id=16616864#.T-WaQhc7Xko|publisher=ABC News|date=June 21, 2012}} As they struggled on the ground, Zimmerman on his back with Martin on top of him, Zimmerman yelled for help "probably 50 times". (See [[#Background yells for help in 9-1-1 calls|Background yells for help in 9-1-1 calls]]) Martin told him to "Shut the fuck up" as he hit him in the face and pounded his head on a concrete sidewalk. When Zimmerman tried to move off the concrete, Martin saw his gun and said "You're going to die tonight motherfucker!" Martin grabbed for the gun, but Zimmerman grabbed it first. He said after firing his weapon at Martin, he was not sure at first that he had hit him, so he got on top of him in order to subdue him.{{cite news |author1=Robles, Frances|author2=Caputo, Marc|lastauthoramp=yes|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/06/21/v-fullstory/2860569/zimmerman-told-police-trayvon.html|title=Tapes show Sanford Police grew skeptical of Zimmerman's story|work=Miami Herald|date=June 21, 2012|accessdate=July 11, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712194615/http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/06/21/v-fullstory/2860569/zimmerman-told-police-trayvon.html|archivedate=July 12, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Also published nationally by [[McClatchy Newspapers]] as "[https://web.archive.org/web/20120622182303/http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2012/06/21/153397/zimmerman-said-martin-assured.html George Zimmerman said Trayvon Martin assured him he was going to kill him]" Bystanders and police arrived shortly after Martin was shot.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/05/18/us/new-details-are-released-in-shooting-of-teenager.html?_r=3&hp | work=The New York Times |first1=Serge F. |last1=Kovaleski | first2=Campbell | last2=Robertson | title=New Details Are Released in Shooting of Trayvon Martin |date=May 17, 2012}}[http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/state/autopsy-results-show-trayvon-martin-had-injuries-to-2358129.html "Autopsy results show Trayvon Martin had injuries to his knuckles"], WFTV Channel 9, May 15, 2012. Police reports state Zimmerman "appeared to have a broken and a bloody nose and swelling of his face". Zimmerman was offered three chances to be taken to the hospital, but declined each time, according to police reports released by the prosecution. ABC News reported that a medical report compiled by Zimmerman's family physician showed that, following the altercation with Martin, Zimmerman was diagnosed with a [[closed fracture]] of his nose, two [[black eye]]s, [[laceration]]s to the back of his head, a minor back injury, and bruising in his upper lip and cheek.{{cite news |title=ABC News Exclusive: Zimmerman Medical Report Shows Broken Nose, Lacerations After Trayvon Martin Shooting|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/george-zimmerman-medical-report-sheds-light-injuries-trayvon/story?id=16353532|work=ABC World News|publisher=Yahoo! – ABC News Network|accessdate=May 15, 2013}} In the course of Zimmerman's recorded interviews, Detective Chris Serino questioned aspects of Zimmerman's account, such as Zimmerman's statement that he didn't know the name of a street in the Twin Lakes community where he had lived for three years. Zimmerman said in response that he had a bad memory and takes medication for [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]]. Investigators also questioned the extent of his injuries and why he didn't identify himself to Martin as a Neighborhood Watch coordinator. Zimmerman said he didn't want to confront Martin. On June 26, 2012, the prosecution released the results of a voice stress test performed on George Zimmerman the day after the shooting.{{cite news|url=http://www.wjla.com/articles/2012/06/george-zimmerman-told-truth-about-trayvon-martin-shooting-documents-state-77322.html|title=George Zimmerman told truth about Trayvon Martin shooting, documents state|publisher=ABC News (local)|date=June 26, 2012|accessdate=June 26, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.wtsp.com/news/article/261165/19/More-George-Zimmerman-evidence-released|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130209183309/http://www.wtsp.com/news/article/261165/19/More-George-Zimmerman-evidence-released|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 9, 2013|title=Trayvon Martin Shooting: More George Zimmerman evidence released|publisher=WTSB Tampa Bay|date=June 26, 2012|accessdate=June 26, 2012}} Zimmerman was asked, "Did you confront the guy you shot?", to which Zimmerman answered, "No." Zimmerman was asked, "Were you in fear for your life, when you shot the guy?", to which Zimmerman answered, "Yes." The examiner concluded that Zimmerman "told substantially the complete truth" in the examination, and Zimmerman was classified as "No Deception Indicated (NDI)" according to the report. During a bond hearing on April 20, 2012, Investigator Dale Gilbreath testified under oath that he did not know whether Zimmerman or Martin started the fight and that there is no evidence to contradict Zimmerman's claim that he was walking back to his vehicle when Martin confronted him. Gilbreath, however, questioned Zimmerman's statement that Martin was slamming his head against the sidewalk just before he shot the teenager, saying it was "not consistent with the evidence we found."{{cite news|title='I Am Sorry,' Zimmerman Says as Bail Set at $150,000|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/21/us/george-zimmerman-bail-hearing.html|agency=|accessdate=August 13, 2013|work = The New York Times|date = April 21, 2012|first1=Serge F.|last1=Kovaleski|first2=Jennifer|last2=Preston}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-201_162-57418405/experts-zimmerman-attorney-made-smart-move/|title=Experts: Zimmerman attorney made smart move|publisher=CBS News|date=April 21, 2012|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-04-20/news/os-george-zimmerman-bond-hearing-20120420_1_special-prosecutor-angela-corey-robert-zimmerman-soni|title=George Zimmerman granted $150K bond, apologizes to Trayvon Martin's family|author=Stutzman, Rene|work=Orlando Sentinel Times|date=April 21, 2012|accessdate=June 9, 2012}} Gilbreath was one of two investigators who attested to the facts stated in the [[probable cause]] affidavit. ====Zimmerman's first media interview==== On July 18, 2012, Zimmerman, accompanied by his attorney [[Mark O'Mara]], gave his first long media interview to [[Sean Hannity]], and part of the interview appeared on ''[[Hannity]]'' that evening. During the interview, Zimmerman said that he did not regret his actions on the night of the shooting and that he felt that what had happened "was all God's plan". He also said, "I do wish there was something, anything I could have done that wouldn't have put me in the position where I had to take his life. I want to tell everyone, my wife, my family, my parents, grandmother, the Martins, the city of Sanford and America: I'm sorry that this happened. I'm truly sorry." When Hannity asked Zimmerman why his suspicions were aroused when he noticed Martin, Zimmerman replied in part:
I felt he was suspicious because it was raining. He was in-between houses, cutting in-between houses, and he was walking very leisurely for the weather.... It didn't look like he was a resident that went to check their mail and got caught in the rain and was hurrying back home. He didn't look like a fitness fanatic that would train in the rain.{{cite web|author=Joy-Ann Reid |url=http://thegrio.com/2012/07/18/zimmerman-says-he-was-not-pursuing-trayvon-martin/ |title=Zimmerman tells Hannity: 'No regrets' over his actions in Trayvon Martin shooting |publisher=The Grio |date=July 18, 2012 |accessdate=September 28, 2012}}{{cite news| url=http://video.foxnews.com/v/1741879195001/ | publisher=Fox News Channel | title=Exclusive: George Zimmerman breaks silence on 'Hannity{{'-}} | date=July 18, 2012}}
Following the interview with Hannity, Special Prosecutor Angela Corey filed formal notice that she intended to use the interview as evidence against Zimmerman.{{cite news|title=Special prosecutor will use George Zimmerman's Fox News interview against him|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-07-19/news/os-george-zimmerman-interview-react-20120719_1_trayvon-martin-special-prosecutor-angela-corey-george-zimmerman|first=Rene|last=Stutzman|first2=Jeff|last2=Weiner|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=July 19, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2012}} According to an article in the ''Orlando Sentinel'', Zimmerman's story differed in at least two details from previous versions of what he said happened the night he shot Martin—specifically, that he told Hannity he had walked toward Martin because he was trying to find a street address to provide the police, but during the police's investigation he had said that the reason he approached Martin was that he was looking for the name of the street, which he had forgotten; and that he told Hannity that Martin had been "skipping, going away quickly", not running away out of fear, but he had previously told Sanford police that Martin had run away as Zimmerman was reporting him. Florida defense lawyers said it was a mistake for Zimmerman to do a television interview and discuss what happened that night. One of them said, "It's really baffling what he thought he'd gain from it. I question who's in charge of the defense strategy, Zimmerman or O'Mara". O'Mara told reporters that the interview was intended to help increase the number of donations to Zimmerman's nearly exhausted legal defense fund, which would pay the costs for Zimmerman's legal defense as well as for shelter and security.{{cite news|title=Zimmerman interview part of plan to promote website, raise more defense funds|url=http://www.wftv.com/news/news/local/zimmerman-interview-part-plan-raise-more-defense-f/nPygj/|publisher=WFTV 9|date=July 19, 2012}} O'Mara said that Zimmerman had promised Hannity three months earlier that he would give his first interview to Hannity, and that Hannity had agreed to promote Zimmerman's website during the interview, although he said Hannity did not. ABC News' [[Barbara Walters]] also said that Zimmerman was in desperate need of money and was worried about the safety of his family.{{cite news|last=Robles|first=Frances|title=More twists as Zimmerman takes his case public|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/07/19/v-fullstory/2902578/zimmerman-calls-barbara-walter.html|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=July 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202235646/http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/07/19/v-fullstory/2902578/zimmerman-calls-barbara-walter.html|archivedate=December 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}} She had flown from New York to Florida to record a television interview with Zimmerman that was to be shown following the Hannity interview, but the television network refused to meet Zimmerman's request that they pay for a month's hotel stay and security for his wife. Martin's parents said they did not accept Zimmerman's apology for killing their son.{{cite web|last=Morgenstern|first=Madeleine|title=Trayvon's Parents react to Zimmerman Interview and 'God's Plan': 'Don't know what God George Zimmerman is worshiping'|url=http://www.theblaze.com/stories/trayvons-parents-react-to-zimmerman-interview-and-gods-plan-dont-know-what-god-george-zimmerman-is-worshiping/|publisher=The Blaze|accessdate=July 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120722001518/http://www.theblaze.com/stories/trayvons-parents-react-to-zimmerman-interview-and-gods-plan-dont-know-what-god-george-zimmerman-is-worshiping/|archivedate=July 22, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Martin's mother, Sybrina Fulton, said she doubted that Zimmerman's apology was sincere. "I have a hard time accepting it because he also said that he doesn't regret anything that he did that night" Fulton stated.{{cite news|title=Trayvon Martin's parent: this was't Gods plan|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505266_162-57475469/trayvon-martins-parents-this-wasnt-gods-plan/?tag=thisMorningLatest|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=July 19, 2012}} ===Affidavit of probable cause=== On April 11, 2012, an affidavit of probable cause was filed in support of second-degree murder charges against Zimmerman. The affidavit described what investigators alleged took place between Zimmerman and Martin on the night of the shooting.{{cite news|title=State of Florida vs. George Zimmerman: Affidavit of probable cause|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/04/12/us/13shooter-document.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 11, 2012|date=April 12, 2012}}{{cite news|title=George Zimmerman charged|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-04-12/news/os-trayvon-martin-george-zimmerman-charged-jail-20120412_1_face-murder-charges-today-show-accident|work=Orlando Sentinel|date = April 12, 2012|first=Rene|last=Stutzman|first2=Arelis R.|last2=Hernandez|accessdate=June 14, 2012}}{{cite news|title=Affidavit says Zimmerman profiled Martin|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-04-12/justice/justice_florida-teen-shooting_1_police-dispatcher-affidavit-gated-community?_s=PM:JUSTICE|publisher=CNN|accessdate=May 11, 2012|date=March 27, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717224807/http://articles.cnn.com/2012-04-12/justice/justice_florida-teen-shooting_1_police-dispatcher-affidavit-gated-community?_s=PM:JUSTICE|archivedate=July 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|last=Alvarez Lizette|first=Kovaleski Serge|title=A Day in Court and a New Lawyer for Defendant in Martin Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/13/us/george-zimmerman-to-appear-in-court.html?_r=1|work=The New York Times|accessdate=May 11, 2012|date=April 12, 2012}}{{cite news |last=Dade|first=Corey|title=Affidavit reveals new details in case against George Zimmerman|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2012/04/12/150525253/affidavit-reveals-new-details-in-case-against-george-zimmerman|publisher=NPR|accessdate=May 11, 2012}} Prosecutors alleged that Zimmerman profiled Martin as he was walking back from a nearby 7-Eleven store to the townhouse where he was temporarily living. Prosecutors said Zimmerman was driving in his vehicle when he saw Martin and assumed he was a criminal and perceived that Martin was acting suspicious and felt that he did not belong in the gated community. Zimmerman called the police, and prosecutors said the dispatcher told Zimmerman an officer was on the way and to wait for him. In the call, Zimmerman made reference to people he felt had gotten away with break-ins in the neighborhood.{{#tag:ref|While talking about Martin, Zimmerman stated "these assholes, they always get away" and also said "these fucking punks.|group="Note"}} Investigators alleged that while Zimmerman was talking to the dispatcher, Martin was on the phone with a friend and she said that Martin was scared because he was being followed by an unknown man. Investigators said that Martin attempted to run home, but Zimmerman followed him because he didn't want Martin to get away. When the police dispatcher realized Zimmerman was following Martin, he told Zimmerman that was unnecessary and that police would meet him there. Prosecutors alleged that Zimmerman ignored the dispatcher and continued following Martin and confronted him and a struggle ensued. When police arrived at the scene, Zimmerman admitted to shooting Martin in the chest. ====Analysis of charges==== Legal analysts criticized the prosecution for over-charging Zimmerman, claiming that the probable cause affidavit did not support a charge of second-degree murder.{{cite news|title=Dershowitz: Prosecutor in Trayvon Martin case overreached with murder charge|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2012/04/25/dershowitz-trayvon-prosecutor-overreached-with-murder-charge/?test=latestnews|publisher=Fox News Channel|author=Wilson, Greg|date=April 25, 2012|accessdate=June 9, 2012}}{{cite news |title=Second-degree murder charge may be hard to prove in Trayvon Martin case|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/04/11/2743404/second-degree-murder-charge-may.html|work=Miami Herald |author=Hiassen, Scott|author2=Ovalle, David|date=April 12, 2012|archiveurl=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/second-degree-murder-charge-may-be-hard-to-prove-i/nN26Z/|archivedate=April 12, 2012}} Harvard Law Professor Alan Dershowitz claimed the affidavit may have been perjurious if Special Prosecutor [[Angela Corey]] knowingly omitted facts favorable to Zimmerman's self-defense claim. Richard Kuritz, a former prosecutor who worked with Angela Corey, said the state attorney had no obligation to include exculpatory evidence in the affidavit. He stated that Dershowitz could face [[civil action]] for making accusations that Corey committed a crime. "To suggest that she's committing any crime, Dershowitz is way off on that", Kuritz said.{{cite news|last=Broward|first=Charles|title=Angela Corey takes on well known legal commentator, Harvard professor Alan Dershowitz|url=http://jacksonville.com/news/crime/2012-06-07/story/angela-corey-takes-well-known-legal-commentator-harvard-professor-alan#ixzz1xDH6Ib4z|work=The Florida Times Union|accessdate=July 16, 2012}} ===Background yells for help in 9-1-1 calls=== In recordings of the [[9-1-1]] calls, yells for help are audible in the background. Zimmerman's family says it was Zimmerman yelling for help, Martin's family says it was Martin yelling for help, and independent audio analysts offer differing opinions as to who was yelling for help. During the trial, friends and family members of both Zimmerman and Martin testified as to who they thought the voice was, but expert testimony regarding voice identification was not allowed.State of Florida v. George Zimmerman, No. 12-CF-1083-A (Seminole County 18th Circ. 2013). In an interview with prosecutors on March 19, Zimmerman's father identified the yells as George Zimmerman's, stating, "There is no doubt who is yelling for help. It is absolutely my son." [[Bill O'Reilly (political commentator)|Bill O'Reilly]] of Fox News called for restraint and urged other [[pundit]]s to stop trying the case in the media. He said that the case is a "tragedy" but should not be tried in the media.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/oreilly/2012/05/17/bill-oreilly-stunning-new-developments-trayvon-martin-case|title=Bill O'Reilly: The media not backing off from trying the Trayvon Martin case on TV|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=May 17, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120520191101/http://www.foxnews.com/on-air/oreilly/2012/05/17/bill-oreilly-stunning-new-developments-trayvon-martin-case|archivedate=May 20, 2012|df=mdy-all}} After Zimmerman's bond was revoked for misrepresenting how much money he had when his bond was set,{{cite news|title=Judge revokes Zimmerman's bond|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-06-01/justice/justice_florida-teen-shooting_1_second-passport-judge-revokes-credit-union?_s=PM:JUSTICE|publisher=CNN|accessdate=June 5, 2012|date=January 29, 2004|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120605014722/http://articles.cnn.com/2012-06-01/justice/justice_florida-teen-shooting_1_second-passport-judge-revokes-credit-union?_s=PM:JUSTICE|archivedate=June 5, 2012|df=mdy-all}} Martin family attorney Benjamin Crump said he expected the prosecution to bring Zimmerman's credibility "front and center in this entire case".{{cite news|title=Zimmerman back to jail; judge says he lied|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/zimmerman-back-jail-judge-says-he-lied|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=June 5, 2012|date=June 2, 2012}} Republished and revised in ''USA Today'' as "[https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-06-02/zimmerman-credibility/55346970/1 Zimmerman credibility may be issue in Martin case]". Zimmerman's attorney, Mark O'Mara stated that it was a "mistake" that had "undermined his credibility, which he will have to work to repair".{{cite news|last=Pearce|first=Matt|title=George Zimmerman has undermined his credibility, defense admits|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-zimmermans-lawyer-undermined-credibility-20120604,0,5710222.story|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=June 5, 2012|date=June 4, 2012}} ==Alleged race issues== ===Allegations against Zimmerman=== [[File:Occupy Chicago protestors (11).jpg|thumb|Chicago protestors on March 28, 2012]] Zimmerman was accused of being motivated by racism and of having [[Racial profiling|racially profiled]] Martin.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/19/us/911-tapes-released-in-killing-of-florida-teenager.html|title=911 Calls Add Detail to Debate Over Florida Killing|last=Alvarez|first=Lizette|date=March 17, 2012|work=The New York Times|accessdate=March 20, 2012}} During early media coverage of the incident, Zimmerman's call to the police dispatcher was [[Shooting of Trayvon Martin#Deceptive audio editing by NBC|misleadingly edited by NBC]] so that it appeared that Zimmerman had volunteered Martin's race. The unedited audio recording proved that the police dispatcher specifically asked about Martin's race, and only then did Zimmerman reveal that Martin was black. NBC apologized for the misleading edit and disciplined those involved.{{cite news |last=Wemple |first=Erik |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/post/nbc-to-do-internal-investigation-on-zimmerman-segment/2012/03/31/gIQAc4HhnS_blog.html |title=NBC to do 'internal investigation' on Zimmerman segment |work=The Washington Post |date=March 31, 2012}} Other reproaches to Zimmerman include his extensive history of 911 calls and an alleged obsession with law and order and the minutiae of suburban life."[https://www.motherjones.com/documents/327330-george-zimmerrman-911-call-history George Zimmerman's Police Call History]". Mother Jones. Retrieved January 3, 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.loop21.com/life/george-zimmerman-911-call-history |title=George Zimmerman's History of 911 Calls on Black Men |publisher=Loop 21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225211335/http://www.loop21.com/life/george-zimmerman-911-call-history |archivedate=December 25, 2013 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2012/03/trayvon-shooters-911-calls-potholes-piles-trash-black-men |title=Trayvon Shooter's 911 Calls: Potholes, Piles of Trash—and Black Men |publisher=Mother Jones}}{{dubious|date=July 2016}} ====Defense of Zimmerman's character==== In an [[open letter]] on March 15, 2012, Zimmerman's father, Robert Zimmerman, defended his son against allegations that his actions were racially motivated, stating that Zimmerman was [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic]], was raised in a multiracial family, and "would be the last to discriminate for any reason whatsoever", saying that the portrayal of his son as a racist "could not be further from the truth". Just as George Zimmerman's trial was set to begin, Robert Zimmerman published an [[e-book]] about the case in which he said that prior to the shooting, he had generally believed racism was no longer much of a problem and that he had personally not experienced much racism, despite being married to a Hispanic woman, but that since the shooting he had found that racism is "flourishing at the insistence of some in the African American Community".{{cite news|last=Legum|first=Judd|title=George Zimmerman's father says the 'true racists' are African-American|url=http://thinkprogress.org/media/2013/06/14/2162501/george-zimmermans-father-says-the-true-racists-are-all-african-american/| publisher=ThinkProgress |date=June 14, 2013}} In a chapter called "Who are the True Racists", Robert Zimmerman listed a host of African Americans he says are racist, including the [[Congressional Black Caucus]], the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]], the [[National Basketball Players Association]], the [[National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives]], the [[National Black Chamber of Commerce]], and the [[United Negro College Fund]], among others. According to George Zimmerman's family, some of Zimmerman's relatives are black. Zimmerman's former lawyer Craig Sonner stated that Zimmerman is not a racist, and that he had mentored black youths in the past.[http://www.cnn.com/video/#/video/us/2012/03/24/ac-sonner-trayvon-martin-shooting.cnn "Zimmerman atty.: Shooting isn't racist"]. CNN. March 23, 2012 Joe Oliver, a former television news reporter who is acquainted with Zimmerman,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/post/dont-trust-joe-olivers-gut-feeling-about-his-friend-george-zimmerman/2011/03/04/gIQAnalogS_blog.html|title=Don't trust Joe Oliver's 'gut feeling' about his 'friend' George Zimmerman|last=Capehart|first=Jonathan|date=March 28, 2012|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=March 28, 2012}} noted "I'm a black male and all that I know is that George has never given me any reason whatsoever to believe he has anything against people of color."Trotta, Daniel (March 25, 2012). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/25/us-usa-florida-shooting-friend-idUSBRE82O0FE20120325 "Black friend defends shooter of Florida teen"]. Reuters In early April, an anonymous letter to the NAACP, which was signed "A Concerned Zimmerman Family Member" said Zimmerman had been one of the few to take any action to protest the 2010 beating of Sherman Ware, a black homeless man, by the son of a Sanford police officer. Zimmerman reportedly distributed fliers in the black community trying to get others involved too, and helped organize a January 8, 2011, Sanford City Hall community forum to protest the incident.{{cite web | url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/04/02/zimmerman-family-member-calls-naacp-racists-says-there-will-be-blood-on-your-hands-if-george-is-hurt/| title=Zimmerman family member calls NAACP 'racists,' says 'there will be blood on your hands' if George is hurt | publisher=Daily Caller | accessdate=April 3, 2012}} Zimmerman's father confirmed his son's efforts on Ware's behalf.[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-04-05/news/os-george-zimmerman-fliers-20120405_1_sherman-ware-justin-collison-robert-zimmerman Zimmerman's family: George handed out fliers, protesting police coddling of white suspect] ''Orlando Sentinel'' (April 5, 2012) In May, the Miami Herald secured an audiotape of the January 8, 2011, Sanford City Hall community forum. On the audiotape, Zimmerman was heard criticizing the conduct of the Sanford Police Department in the Ware case. Zimmerman criticized former chief, Brian Tooley, and said Tooley had engaged in a "cover-up" and that he should lose his pension. He also said he'd been on ride-alongs with Sanford police where he found them to be lazy. The Herald also reported that it had contacted five out of six black churches where Zimmerman was reported to have distributed fliers on the Ware beating, however no one recalled receiving them. On July 12, 2012, reports of some of the more than 30 interviews conducted by the FBI were publicly released. Sanford Police investigator Chris Serino told FBI agents that he believed Zimmerman's actions were not based on Martin's race. Zimmerman's neighbors had nothing derogatory to say about him, and his co-workers were complimentary. CNN headlined its article on the FBI interviews "Witnesses tell FBI that George Zimmerman is no racist". ===Allegations against Martin=== During the trial, defense attorney Don West implied that the language Martin had allegedly used was evidence that Martin had introduced race into the confrontation.{{cite news|author1=Benn, Evan S.|author2=Burch, Audra D.S.|lastauthoramp=yes|title=Trayvon Martin's childhood friend back on the witness stand in Zimmerman trial|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/06/26/v-fullstory/3471243/alternate-juror-dismissed-in-trayvon.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130814080342/http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/06/26/v-fullstory/3471243/alternate-juror-dismissed-in-trayvon.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=August 14, 2013|work=Miami Herald|date=June 26, 2013|accessdate=August 14, 2013}} State's Witness 8, Rachel Jeantel, testified that Martin, during his telephone conversation with her just prior to the shooting, had referred to Zimmerman as a "creepy-ass cracker".{{cite news |last=Muller|first=Sarah|title=Zimmerman case: Is Rachel Jeantel on trial, too?|url=http://tv.msnbc.com/2013/06/29/zimmerman-case-is-rachel-jeantel-on-trial-too/|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=July 3, 2013}} On cross-examination, West asked Jeantel, "So it was racial, but it was because Trayvon Martin put race in this?" and "You don't think that 'creepy ass cracker' is a racial comment?"{{cite news|title=Contentious testimony in Zimmerman trial|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1306/27/acd.01.html|work=[[Anderson Cooper 360]]|publisher=CNN|date=June 27, 2013}} Jeantel replied that she believed race was involved because Martin was being followed by a white man, not because Martin had called Zimmerman a "creepy-ass cracker."{{cite news|author=Alcindor, Yamiche|title=Trayvon Martin's friend: Encounter was racially charged|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/06/27/trayvon-martin-sanford-zimmerman-florida-race/2462403/|work=USA Today|date=June 27, 2013|accessdate=July 3, 2013}}{{cite news her community call white people "cracker" and she did not find the term offensive.{{cite news |title=Rachel Jeantel faces 2nd day of questioning in George Zimmerman trial|url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/rachel-jeantel-returns-to-stand-in-george-zimmerman-murder-trial/-/1637132/20735920/-/hbqre8/-/index.html|publisher=WKMG|accessdate=July 3, 2013}}{{cite focus|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/george-zimmerman-trial-race-is-a-subtext-not-the-focus/2013/07/02/a296611e-e262-11e2-a11e-c2ea876a8f30_singlePage.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 3, 2013|first=Manuel|last=Roig-Franzia}} Jeantel also testified that Martin, during his telephone conversation, referred to Zimmerman as a "[[nigga]]." Jeantel said that Martin's use of the word "nigga" to describe Zimmerman was "slang"{{cite news |title=Friend on phone with Martin at time of death: I heard him say 'Get off, get off'|url=http://news.ca.msn.com/top-stories/friend-on-phone-with-martin-at-time-of-death-i-heard-him-say-get-off-get-off|publisher=MSN|accessdate=15 August 2013}} when asked by lead prosecutor Bernie De La Rionda. ===Allegations against the Sanford police=== For not arresting Zimmerman, the Sanford police faced heavy criticism, protests, and allegations of racial bias. The NAACP wrote [[U.S. Attorney General]] [[Eric Holder]] expressing "no confidence that, absent federal oversight, the [[Sanford Police Department (Florida)|Sanford Police Department]] will devote the necessary degree of care to its investigation" and requesting that personnel be detailed to Sanford to review the case without bias. Lee repeatedly defended the investigation, stating that the Sanford police did not feel they had conducted a racially biased investigation and welcomed a review of their efforts.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/neighborhood-watch-shooting-trayvon-martin-probe-reveals-questionable/story?id=15907136 |title=Orlando Watch Shooting Probe Reveals Questionable Police Conduct|last=Gutman|first=Matt|date=March 13, 2012|publisher=ABC News |accessdate=March 20, 2012}} Allegations were also made that the Sanford police were protecting Zimmerman. Lee told reporters that they could not arrest Zimmerman because no evidence contradicted his story, and that to do so would leave the police open to litigation. In regards to the 9-1-1 dispatcher telling Zimmerman that "We don't need you to [follow him]",Clint Van Zandt, [http://video.msnbc.msn.com/newsnation/46786334 911 calls released in deadly Florida shooting], MSNBC. Retrieved March 21, 2012. Lee said "That is a call taker making a recommendation to him. He's not under a legal obligation to do that, so that is not something we can charge him with." On March 21, 2012, three out of the five members of the Sanford City Commission, including the mayor, passed a [[motion of no confidence]] in regards to the Police Chief Bill Lee, and his handling of the case; however, the vote was advisory only.{{cite news |url=http://www.clickorlando.com/news/Mayor-2-others-pass-motion-of-no-confidence-in-police-chief/-/1637132/9655648/-/umrfxb/-/index.html|title=Mayor, 2 others vote 'no confidence' in police chief|publisher=WKMG Orlando|accessdate=March 22, 2012}} The following day, Lee announced that he had temporarily stepped down from his position as chief of police, stating "my involvement in this matter is overshadowing the process." Lee further stated, "I do this in the hopes of restoring some semblance of calm to a city which has been in turmoil for several weeks." On April 23, 2012, the city of Sanford announced that Police Chief Bill Lee would resign but city commissioners voted to reject the [[resignation]]. Some commissioners had concerns about the fairness of Lee losing his job and the mayor stated he preferred to wait for the results of an investigation. Lee was to remain on [[paid leave]].{{cite news|title=Florida city commission rejects police chief's resignation in Trayvon Martin case|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/23/justice/florida-teen-shooting/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|publisher=CNN|accessdate=April 24, 2012|date=April 24, 2012}} In an interview with CNN, following his testimony at Zimmerman's trial, Bill Lee said that he felt pressure from city officials to arrest Zimmerman to placate the public rather than as a matter of justice.{{cite news|author=Elliott C. McLaughlin|title=Ex-Sanford police chief: Zimmerman probe 'taken away from us'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/10/justice/sanford-bill-lee-exclusive/index.html|publisher=CNN|date=July 11, 2013|accessdate=July 11, 2013}} Lee said, "It was relayed to me that they just wanted an arrest. They didn't care if it got dismissed later." Lee further stated in the interview that the Sanford Police conducted a "sound" investigation, and the evidence provided no probable cause to arrest Zimmerman at the scene. Lee said that the police needed to do a job, and there was some outside, and inside influence, that "forced a change in the course of the normal criminal justice process." The former police chief said the investigation was taken away from us and "we weren't able to complete it." Lee also said that his lead investigator made a recommendation that Zimmerman be charged with manslaughter, as a matter of protocol. The Sanford police presented a "''capias'' request" to the state's attorney, asking that they determine whether it was a "justifiable homicide". =="Stand your ground" laws== The Zimmerman defense team initially planned to seek to dismiss the case against Zimmerman under the protection afforded by Florida's "[[Stand-your-ground law|stand your ground]]" self-defense law. The controversial law, passed in 2005, permits the use of deadly force when someone reasonably feels he or she is at risk of great bodily harm in a confrontation.{{cite news|last=Caputo|first=Marc|title=Juror: we talked Stand Your Ground before not-guilty Zimmerman verdict|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/07/16/3502481/juror-we-talked-stand-your-ground.html|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=July 18, 2013}} Zimmerman's defense team ultimately did not seek a pretrial hearing for immunity from prosecution based on the stand your ground law.{{cite news|last=Alcindor|first=Yamiche|title=Zimmerman self-defense hearing no longer in April|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/03/05/zimmerman-self-defense-hearing-no-longer-in-april/1964901/|work=USA Today|date=March 5, 2013}}{{cite news |first=Brad |last=Knickerbocker |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/DC-Decoder/2013/0721/Stand-your-ground-laws-rattle-US-politics-society |title='Stand your ground' laws rattle US politics, society |work=The Christian Science Monitor |date=July 21, 2013 |accessdate=July 27, 2013}} However, as required by the stand your ground provision of the law, during the trial the judge instructed the jurors that Zimmerman had had no duty to retreat and had had a right to stand his ground and use deadly force if he reasonably believed doing so was necessary to defend himself. Prior to the passage of Florida's stand your ground law, the standard jury instructions from the judge would have included a statement that a person had a duty to attempt to retreat using "every reasonable means" before using deadly force. [[Self-defense (United States)|Self-defense laws in the United States]], particularly [[Justifiable homicide#United States|regarding justifiable homicide]], vary by state. In many states, such laws exempt people in their own homes from the [[common-law]] requirement that one first [[Duty to retreat|attempt to retreat]], if one can safely do so, before resorting to the use of deadly force (the so-called "[[castle doctrine]]", based on the notion that "a person's home is his castle").{{cite news|last=Chow, J.D.|first=Andrew|title='Stand Your Ground' Laws: State by State|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/22/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-blotter-idUS212849160320120322|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323204107/https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/22/tagblogsfindlawcom2012-blotter-idUS212849160320120322|archivedate=March 23, 2012|agency=Reuters|date=March 21, 2012}} Florida's stand your ground law extends the no-retreat doctrine to vehicles and public places.{{cite news|first=Ashley|last=Portero|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/317624/20120321/floirda-stand-ground-law-explained.htm|title=Florida's 'Stand Your Ground' Law: 5 Things To Know|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=March 21, 2012|accessdate=March 23, 2012}} At the time of Martin's shooting, 22 other states had adopted similar stand your ground laws. Three weeks after the shooting, Florida Governor Rick Scott commissioned a 19-member [[task force]] to review the Florida [[statute]] that deals with justifiable use of force, including the Stand Your Ground provision.{{cite news|title=Task Force to consider 'stand your ground' after Trayvon Martin death |url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/19/justice/florida-stand-your-ground/index.html?hpt=hp_t1 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=April 20, 2012 |date=April 20, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120421021516/http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/19/justice/florida-stand-your-ground/index.html?hpt=hp_t1 |archivedate=April 21, 2012 }} After holding seven public hearings around the state, and reviewing more than 11,000 comments submitted by the public—nearly three times as many of which were opposed to the law as were in support of it,{{#tag:ref| The full tally is availableKonkus, John (November 9, 2012). [http://www.flgov.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/11-12-12-Executive-Summary-of-Citizen-Correspondence.pdf "Executive Summary of Citizen Correspondence"]. (PDF file). [[Rick Scott]]. Retrieved August 14, 2013.|group=Note}} the task force recommended against repealing the statute, saying that Florida residents have a right to defend themselves with deadly force without a duty to retreat if they feel threatened.{{cite news|last=Kam|first=Dara|title=Florida's Stand Your Ground panel: keep self-defense law intact|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/news/news/state-regional-govt-politics/stand-your-ground-panel-keep-self-defense-law-inta/nS5yj/|newspaper=Palm Beach Post|date=November 13, 2012}}{{#tag:ref|The task force's final report is available at {{cite web|url=http://www.flgov.com/citizensafety/ |title=Task Force on Citizens Safety and Protection |publisher=Flgov.com |date=March 22, 2012 |accessdate=July 27, 2013}}|group=Note}} Critics said that the members appointed to the task force had been chosen to heavily bias the panel against any significant changes in the law, and that, as a result, the panel's conclusions were no surprise.{{cite news |last=Olorunnipa |first=Toluse |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/11/13/v-fullstory/3095729/stand-your-ground-task-force-has.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130726072153/http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/11/13/v-fullstory/3095729/stand-your-ground-task-force-has.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 26, 2013 |title=Stand Your Ground task force has little to show for six months of work |work=Miami Herald |date=November 13, 2012 |accessdate=June 12, 2013 }}{{cite news|last=Cotterell|first=Bill|title=Florida task force recommends preserving Stand Your Ground law|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/22/us-usa-florida-guns-idUSBRE91L16I20130222|agency=Reuters|date=February 22, 2013}} The task force did suggest that law enforcement agencies and the courts increase training on the self-defense law to ensure the law is applied fairly, and that the legislature more clearly define the role of neighborhood watch participants to avoid vigilantism and fund a study of how the law had been applied, examining effects such as race, ethnicity, and gender. However, the task force largely rejected recommendations of Miami-Dade County State Attorney Katherine Fernandez-Rundle (one of the task force members) that would have restricted the law, including a recommendation to limit immunity from prosection to defendants who have not provoked a confrontation.{{cite news|last=Edgerton|first=Anna|title=Stand Your Ground motion denied in Janepsy Carballo case|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/12/21/3152093/stand-your-ground-motion-denied.html|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=December 21, 2012}} In January 2013, Martin's mother joined two Democratic lawmakers in Florida and called for the repeal of the state's "stand your ground" law.{{cite news|title=Fla. Democrats want repeal of 'stand your ground'|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/fla-democrats-want-repeal-stand-your-ground|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=January 16, 2013}} Several bills subsequently introduced in the Republican-controlled legislature's 2013 session proposing to repeal or revise the Stand Your Ground provisions of the law died without committee hearings.{{cite news|title=2013 session: which bills passed, which bills failed|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/politics/legislature/2013-session-which-bills-passed-which-bills-failed/2119245|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=May 4, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Olorunnipa|first=Toluse|title=Most gun bills are languishing in firearm-friendly Florida's legislature|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/19/v-fullstory/3295295/most-gun-bills-are-languishing.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130726072250/http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/19/v-fullstory/3295295/most-gun-bills-are-languishing.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 26, 2013|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=March 19, 2013}} Several months following Zimmerman's acquittal, in October 2013 bills to revise Florida's Stand Your Ground law provisions in accordance with several of the suggestions offered in 2012 by the governor's task force began advancing through the Florida legislature with bipartisan support.{{cite news|last=Deslatte|first=Aaron|title=Committee approves 'Stand Your Ground' changes|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/politics/os-trayvon-stand-your-ground-hearing-20131008,0,4708289.story|newspaper=Orlando Sentinel|date=October 8, 2013}} A proposal offered by State Senator David Simmons, a Republican who had served on the governor's task force and who had been a principal author of the original law, and State Senator Chris Smith, the Democratic senate minority leader, would clarify language in the law to deny aggressors in a confrontation from being able to claim immunity under the law, would allow innocent bystanders harmed by a person standing his or her ground to sue for [[negligence]], and would require the establishment of guidelines and training protocols for neighborhood watch programs that would restrict neighborhood watch volunteers to only observing and reporting.{{cite news|last=McGrory|first=Kathleen|title='Stand your ground' revisions win early approval in Florida Senate|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/courts/criminal/stand-your-ground-revisions-win-early-approval-in-florida-senate/2146165|newspaper=Tampa Bay Times|date=October 8, 2013}} The proposal was received favorably by the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, the Florida Sheriffs Association, the state public defenders association, and the NAACP, although several Republican state legislators voted to block the bill's passage and gun rights advocates expressed opposition to several of the proposals. The Dream Defenders, who several weeks earlier had occupied the state capitol demanding that the legislature take up debate on the Stand Your Ground law, said the bill did not go far enough and urged the legislature to repeal the law entirely. ==Media coverage== [[File:Trayvon Martin shooting protest 2012 Shankbone 11.JPG|thumb|left|Trayvon's father Tracy Martin, family attorney Benjamin Crump and mother Sybrina Fulton, at the 'Million Hoodies' protest in [[Union Square (New York City)|Union Square]], New York]] For the first 10 days after Martin's death, the story was covered by only by local media outlets in Florida. In order to bring more attention to the case, Martin family attorney Natalie Jackson sought the assistance of publicist Ryan Julison on March 5. On March 7, 2012, [[Reuters]] covered the story,{{cite news|last=Liston|first=Barbara|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/03/08/us-crime-florida-neighborhoodwatch-idUSBRE82709M20120308|title=Family of Florida boy killed by Neighborhood Watch seeks The [[Project for Excellence in Journalism]] reported that media coverage of the Trayvon Martin case became the first story in 2012 to be featured more than the presidential race. According to the Project, the varying types of media have focused on the case in different ways. An article in the Tampa Bay Times wrote that, "on Twitter, people are outraged at Zimmerman and want justice, while on cable news and talk radio people are discussing the state's laws for self-defense and gun control and on blogs the focus has been on race."{{cite news |last=Deggans|first=Eric|title=Update: Trayvon Martin story now more covered than presidential race|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/media/content/trayvon-martin-update-story-now-more-covered-presidential-race|work=Tampa Bay Times|accessdate=March 31, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004214442/http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/media/content/trayvon-martin-update-story-now-more-covered-presidential-race|archivedate=October 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Fox News host [[Geraldo Rivera]], a former NBC employee, asserted that MSNBC "made an ideological decision that... they would argue strenuously for the prosecution of George Zimmerman and the ultimate conviction of George Zimmerman... Hispanic? White and Hispanic?... or?|url=https://www.pbs.org/ombudsman/2012/04/the_mailbag_white_hispanic_white_and_hispanic.html|publisher=PBS|date=April 12, 2012}} ===Zimmerman's call to police=== Economist and commentator [[Thomas Sowell]] criticized the national media for implying that Zimmerman had continued to follow Martin after the police dispatcher said, "We don't need you to do that." He said that they mostly left out Zimmerman's answer, "O.K." because "too many people in the media see their role as filtering and slanting the news."Sowell, Thomas (April 24, 2012) [http://spectator.org/archives/2012/04/24/who-is-racist "Who is 'Racist'?"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120427075606/http://spectator.org/archives/2012/04/24/who-is-racist |date=April 27, 2012 }} ''The American Spectator''. Retrieved May 3, 2012. After the audio of the call was released, reports by [[CNN]]{{cite news | url=http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2012/03/22/did-trayvon-martins-shooter-use-slur-in-911-tapes/ | title=Did Trayvon Martin's shooter use slur in 911 tapes? | work=Anderson Cooper 360 | publisher=CNN |date=March 22, 2012 | accessdate=April 2, 2012}} and other news outlets alleged that Zimmerman had said "fucking coons" two minutes and twenty-one seconds (2:21) into the call. Two weeks later on April 4, 2012, CNN claimed that enhanced audio revealed that Zimmerman had said "fucking cold" (alluding to ongoing rain in February).[http://ac360.blogs.cnn.com/2012/04/04/george-zimmermans-911-call-audio-enhanced/?hpt=ac_bn2 "911 Tapes From Trayvon Martin Shooting: Was a racial slur uttered?"], CNN Anderson Cooper 360, AC360 Blogs, April 4, 2012. The following day, April 5, 2012, CNN's [[Martin Savidge]] reported that [[forensic]] audio expert Tom Owen claimed it was "fucking punks."[http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/05/justice/florida-teen-shooting/?hpt=hp_t1 "CNN's Martin Savidge reports on forensic analysis of 911 tape"]. CNN. April 6, 2012. It is said to be "fucking punks" in the [[affidavit]] of [[probable cause]], dated April 11, 2012. Other reviewers of the call have offered alternate interpretations of what was said, some labeling it "unintelligible." According to the Associated Press, the alleged racial slur "fed growing outrage over the police department's initial decision not to arrest Zimmerman."{{cite web|url=http://bizsecurity.about.com/od/creatingpolicies/a/A-Transcript-Of-The-George-Zimmerman-Police-Call.htm |title=A Transcript of the George Zimmerman Police Call|author=Deutsch, William |publisher=About.com|date=February 26, 2012 |accessdate=April 21, 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/did-george-zimmerman-complain-about-fcking-cns-in-911-call-before-killing-trayvon-martin/ |title=Did George Zimmerman Complain About 'F*cking C**ns' In 911 Call Before Killing Trayvon Martin? |publisher=Mediaite |date=March 20, 2012 }}{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2012/03/did-george-zimmerman-use-a-racial-slur/254925/ |title=Did George Zimmerman Use A Racial Slur?|first=Ta-Nehisi|last=Coates |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=March 22, 2012}}{{cite news|author=Schneider, Mike |title=Prosecutors: Zimmerman did not use racial slur |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_NEIGHBORHOOD_WATCH_WHAT_ZIMMERMAN_SAID?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |publisher=Associated Press |date=April 13, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420002041/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_NEIGHBORHOOD_WATCH_WHAT_ZIMMERMAN_SAID?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|archivedate=April 20, 2012}} Also published ''The Post-Standard'' (Syracuse, N.Y.) as "[http://www.syracuse.com/news/index.ssf/2012/04/affidavit_george_zimmerman_did.html Affidavit: George Zimmerman did not use racial slur in 911 call]". ===Deceptive audio editing by NBC=== Between March 19 and 27, 2012, the NBC Nightly News, NBC's ''Today'' show, and NBC's network-owned Miami affiliate [[WTVJ]]{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcmiami.com/news/local/NBC6-Zimmerman-Edit-Explanation-148961305.html |title=NBC6 Zimmerman Edit Explanation |publisher=[[WTVJ]] |date=April 25, 2012 |accessdate=June 30, 2013}} ran segments which misleadingly merged parts of Zimmerman's call. On one version of the recording played by NBC, Zimmerman was heard saying, "This guy looks like he's up to no good or he's on drugs or something... He's got his hand in his waistband, and he's a black male."{{cite news |author=Luciano, Lilia|title=Feds to probe shooting of Fla. teen|url=http://www.today.com/video/today/46792880|work=Today|publisher=NBC|accessdate=June 29, 2012|date=March 20, 2012}} Embedded in NBC News article "[http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/03/20/10775671-trayvon-martin-case-to-go-to-grand-jury-fla-state-attorney-announces Trayvon Martin case to go to grand jury, Fla. state attorney announces]" Transcript via LexisNexis here [http://talkleft.com/media/todaylucianomarch20.pdf].{{cite av media |title=Lilia Luciano report on Trayvon Martin, Mar 22|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7UATXarhqo0|work=NBC Today Show|via=YouTube|accessdate=June 29, 2012|date=March 22, 2012}} In another what was played was, "This guy looks like he's up to no good. He looks black." In the original 9-1-1 recording, Zimmerman said: "This guy looks like he's up to no good. Or he's on drugs or something. It's raining and he's just walking around, looking about." The 9-1-1 operator then asked: "OK, and this guy, is he black, white or Hispanic?", and Zimmerman answered, "He looks black." The phrase, "He's got his hand in his waistband, and he's a black male" came several exchanges after that point in the conversation. Erik Wemple of ''The Washington Post'' wrote that NBC's alterations "would more readily paint Zimmerman as a racial profiler. In reality... Zimmerman simply answered a question... Nothing prejudicial at all in responding to such an inquiry... To portray that exchange in a way that wrongs Zimmerman is high editorial malpractice..." NBC issued an apology for "an error made in the production process that we deeply regret,"{{cite news | url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/nbc-news-admits-error-in-editing-george-zimmermans-911-call-apologizes/| title=NBC News Admits 'Error' In Editing George Zimmerman's 911 Call, Apologizes|author=Vamburkar, Meenal| publisher=Mediaite | accessdate=April 4, 2012 | date=April 3, 2012}} but never apologized on the air.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/business/media/tv-news-corrects-itself-just-not-on-the-air.htm | work=The New York Times | first=David | last=Carr | title=TV News Corrects Itself, Just Not on the Air | date=April 22, 2012}} The network said that the ''Today'' show and Miami edits took place in two separate incidents involving different people. A Miami-based NBC News producer lost her job, WTVJ reporter Jeff Burnside was fired,{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvspy/wtvj-reporter-fired-for-making-similar-edit-in-george-zimmerman-911-call_b46599 |title=NBC Station Fires Reporter For Making Similar Edit in George Zimmerman 911 Call – TVSpy |publisher=Mediabistro.com |date=April 25, 2012 |accessdate=June 30, 2013}} and two other employees were disciplined.{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/04/25/2767769/nbc6-fires-local-reporter-in-editing.html |first=Frances |last=Robles |title=NBC6 fires local reporter Jeff Burnside in editing of Zimmerman police call |newspaper=Miami Herald |date=April 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429154945/http://www.miamiherald.com/2012/04/25/2767769/nbc6-fires-local-reporter-in-editing.html |archivedate=April 29, 2012 }}{{cite news |url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/06/nbc-fires-producer-of-misleading-zimmerman-tape/|title=NBC Fires Producer of Misleading Zimmerman Tape |last=Stelter|first=Brian | authorlink = Brian Stelter |date=April 6, 2012 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=April 6, 2012}} [[Lilia Luciano]], who was the reporter on broadcasts containing both edited versions of the audio, was also fired, and some of her aired reports on the Trayvon Martin story, along with the misleading audio, were removed from the NBC News website.{{cite web|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/lilia-luciano-fired-misleading-edit_b125484|title=Another Misleading Edit Costs Another NBC News Employee Her Job|publisher=TVNewser.com|last=Ariens|first=Chris|accessdate=May 3, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/03/lilia-luciano-fired-nbc-news-george-zimmerman_n_1475454.html|title=Lilia Luciano Fired By NBC News Over Botched George Zimmerman Edit|publisher=The Huffington Post|first=Jack|last=Mirkinson |date=May 3, 2012|accessdate=May 3, 2012}} On December 6, 2012, Zimmerman filed a defamation lawsuit against NBC alleging that they intentionally edited the phone call so that Zimmerman would sound racist. The lawsuit said, "NBC saw the death of Trayvon Martin not as a tragedy but as an opportunity to increase ratings, and so set about to create the myth that George Zimmerman was a racist and predatory villain."{{cite news|author=Schneider, Mike|title=George Zimmerman sues NBC and reporters|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/george-zimmerman-sues-nbc-and-reporters-0|accessdate=December 7, 2012|date=December 6, 2012|publisher=Associated Press}}{{cite news|last=Martinez|first=Michael|title=George Zimmerman sues NBC Universal over edited 911 call|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/12/06/us/florida-zimmerman-nbc-lawsuit/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=December 7, 2012|date=December 7, 2012}} A NBC spokeswoman said the network strongly disagreed with the accusations that Zimmerman made in the complaint, stating, "There was no intent to portray Mr. Zimmerman unfairly and we intend to vigorously defend our position in court."{{cite news|title=George Zimmerman sues NBC and reporters|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2012/12/06/george-zimmerman-sues-nbc/1752149/|work=USA Today|accessdate=February 4, 2013|date=December 6, 2012}} In June 2014, a summary judgment was issued in the network's favor which ended the lawsuit filed by Zimmerman. In the ruling, the judge wrote that there was "no clear and convincing evidence that defendants knew that the information published was false at the time it was published, or recklessly disregarded the truth or falsity of those statements".{{cite news |author=Stanglin, Doug|title=Court rules for NBC in George Zimmerman defamation case|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2014/06/30/george-zimmerman-trayvon-martin-nbc-news/11759123/|publisher=USA Today |date=June 30, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2014}}{{cite news |author=Stutzman, Rene|title=Judge throws out George Zimmerman's libel suit against NBC |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/trayvon-martin/os-george-zimmerman-nbc-suit-dead-20140630,0,1401290.story|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date=June 30, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2014}} ===Surveillance video mistake=== [[ABC News]] obtained a surveillance video of Zimmerman walking unassisted into the Sanford police station after the shooting. An officer is seen pausing to look at the back of Zimmerman's head, but ABC originally said that no abrasions or blood can be seen in the video.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNT/trayvon-martin-case-exclusive-surveillance-video-george-zimmerman/story?id=16022897 |title=Trayvon Martin Video Shows No Blood or Bruises on George Zimmerman|last=Gutman|first=Matt|date=March 28, 2012|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=March 29, 2012}} ''[[The Daily Caller]]'' disputed this claim, and posted a still from the ABC video which showed an injury on the back of Zimmerman's head.[http://dailycaller.com/2012/03/29/police-surveillance-video-of-zimmerman-may-show-head-injury/ "Police surveillance video of Zimmerman may show head injury"],'' The Daily Caller'', March 29, 2012 ABC later reported that it had "re-digitized" the video, and said that this version showed "what appear to be a pair of gashes or welts on George Zimmerman's head," but the story's main focus was on a doctor who claimed it was unlikely that Zimmerman's nose had been broken.{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/trayvon-martin-case-doctor-sees-evidence-george-zimmerman/story?id=16055412|title=George Zimmerman Video Shows Little Evidence of a Broken Nose, Doctor Claims|author=Matt Gutman|date=April 2, 2012|publisher=ABC News|work=Good Morning America}}[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-04-02/news/os-trayvon-martin-enhanced-video-040212_1_reporter-matt-gutman-abc-news-neighborhood-watch-volunteer-zimmerman "Trayvon Martin: ABC enhances George Zimmerman video"], ''Orlando Sentinel'', April 2, 2012 ===Juror B29 controversy=== In his July 26, 2013, column, ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' journalist [[William Saletan]] accused several major news organizations of editing interviews with "Juror B29" to make it appear that she maintained Zimmerman had gotten away with murder when, according to Saletan, she had not actually done so.{{cite news |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/frame_game/2013/07/did_george_zimmerman_get_away_with_murder_no_juror_b29_is_being_framed.single.html|title=Did George Zimmerman Get Away With Murder? -- The media are reporting that a juror says Zimmerman is guilty of murder. That's not true.|author=William Saletan|date=July 26, 2013|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=July 28, 2013}} ==Trial and verdict== {{Main|Trial of George Zimmerman}} As news of the case spread, thousands of protesters across the country called for Zimmerman's arrest and a full investigation.{{cite news|title=From coast to coast, protestors demand justice in Trayvon Martin case|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/03/26/justice/florida-teen-shooting-events|publisher=CNN|date=March 27, 2012}} On April 11, 2012, amid widespread, intense, and in some cases misleading [[Shooting of Trayvon Martin#Media coverage|media coverage]],{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/06/nbc-fires-producer-of-misleading-tape_n_1409405.html |title= NBC Fires Producer Of Misleading Zimmerman Tape |publisher= [[The Huffington Post]] |date= April 7, 2012 |accessdate= July 20, 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131026070221/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/06/nbc-fires-producer-of-misleading-tape_n_1409405.html |archivedate= October 26, 2013 |df= mdy-all }}{{cite web|url= http://www.deadline.com/2012/05/third-person-exits-nbc-over-misleading-edit-of-zimmermans-911-audio/ |title=Third Person Exits NBC Over Misleading Edit Of Zimmerman's 911 Audio |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= May 12, 2012|accessdate=July 19, 2013}} Zimmerman was charged with [[First degree murder in the United States|second-degree murder]]{{cite news|last1=Chappell|first1=Bill|title=Zimmerman Arrested On Murder Charge In Martin Case; Will Plead Not Guilty|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2012/04/11/150449405/zimmerman-arrested-on-murder-charge-in-martin-case|accessdate=20 October 2016|agency=NPR News|date=April 11, 2012}} by a [[Angela Corey|special prosecutor]] appointed by Governor [[Rick Scott]].{{cite news|last=McClam |first=Erin |url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/06/10/18880979-potential-trayvon-martin-case-jurors-get-look-at-defendant-george-zimmerman?lite |title=Potential Trayvon Martin case jurors get look at defendant George Zimmerman |publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=June 10, 2013|accessdate=June 10, 2013}} [[Trial of George Zimmerman|Zimmerman's trial]] began on June 10, 2013, in Sanford. Opening statements took place on June 24, 2013. Jury deliberations began on July 12. On July 13, 2013, the jury found him not guilty.{{cite news|last=Campo |first=Arian |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324879504578603562762064502 |title=Jury Acquits Zimmerman of All Charges |work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 14, 2013|accessdate=July 14, 2013}}{{cite av media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QjTfvEvtldg |title=George Zimmerman Trial Verdict, Not Guilty: Jury Reads Zimmerman Verdict|work=The Wall Street Journal |date=July 13, 2013 |via=YouTube|accessdate=July 24, 2013}} On February 24, 2015, the [[United States Department of Justice]] announced that "there was not enough evidence for a [[Hate crime laws in the United States|federal hate crime]] prosecution."{{cite news|last=Berman |first=Mark |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/02/24/george-zimmerman-wont-face-civil-rights-charges-in-trayvon-martins-death/ |title=George Zimmerman won't face civil rights charges in Trayvon Martin's death |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=2015-02-24 |accessdate=2016-07-08}} ==Aftermath== Some legal scholars, including Charles Rose of Stetson University and [[Jonathan Turley]] of George Washington University, were not surprised by the verdict and said the prosecution had tactically erred by charging Zimmerman with second-degree murder, which, given Florida's laws on self-defense, made it almost impossible for the prosecution to prove their case beyond a reasonable doubt with the evidence at their disposal.{{cite news|last=Savage|first=David G.|title=Zimmerman verdict: legal experts say prosecutors overreached|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-zimmerman-legal-20130715,0,1600588.story|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=July 14, 2013}}[https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/07/14/zimmerman-trayvon-martin-lawyers-verdict/2516065/ Zimmerman verdict no surprise to many lawyers]. ''USA Today''. July 14, 2013. Retrieved July 18, 2013.{{cite news|title=Questions following the acquittal of George Zimmerman|url=http://thedianerehmshow.org/shows/2013-07-15/questions-following-acquittal-george-zimmerman/transcript|work=Diane Rehm Show |publisher=NPR|date=July 15, 2013}} Several attorneys commenting on the case, such as [[Paul Butler (professor)|Paul Butler]] of Georgetown University, said that the prosecution had failed to adequately prepare their witnesses for trial and had been out-maneuvered by the defense attorneys.{{cite news|title=Inside the Zimmerman verdict|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=202335038|work=Tell Me More|publisher=NPR|date=July 15, 2013}}{{cite news|title=Zimmerman cleared of murder, manslaughter charges|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1307/13/cnr.15.html|publisher=CNN|date=July 13, 2013}} Harvard Law Professor Alan Dershowitz remained extremely critical of State Attorney Angela Corey's actions in the case, charging that "her conduct bordered on criminal conduct" and "in 50 years of litigating cases ... rarely have I seen [a prosecutor] as bad as this prosecutor".{{cite web|title=Dershowitz: Zimmerman Special Prosecutor Angela Corey Should Be Disbarred |url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/video/2013/07/14/alan_dershowitz_zimmerman_special_prosecutor_angela_corey_should_be_disbarred.html|publisher=Real Clear Politics|date=July 14, 2013|accessdate=July 16, 2013}} George Zimmerman remained in hiding after the verdict, although it was reported that on July 17, four days after the verdict, Zimmerman helped rescue several people from an overturned vehicle in Sanford, Florida.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/07/22/us/florida-zimmerman-vehicle/index.html?sr=fb072213zimmermanoverturnedsuv3p |title=Zimmerman helps family out of overturned SUV |publisher=CNN|date=July 22, 2013}} The family rescued by Zimmerman had planned a press conference but later dropped the plan because they were worried about adverse public reaction to saying anything positive about Zimmerman.{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/family-rescued-george-zimmerman-fears-blow-back/story?id=19758908 |title=Family Rescued by George Zimmerman Fears 'Blow Back' |publisher=ABC News |date=July 14, 2013 |accessdate=July 27, 2013}} A month later, Zimmerman was seen in [[Cocoa, Florida]], touring a factory of the company that manufactured the gun he had used in the shooting.{{cite news|last=Liston|first=Barbara|title=Lawyer for George Zimmerman chides him for visiting gun factory|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/08/24/us-usa-zimmerman-gun-idUSBRE97N0CT20130824|publisher=Reuters|date=August 24, 2013}} Zimmerman was said to have asked about the legality of buying Kel-Tec|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/george-zimmerman-visits-florida-gun-maker-kel-tec/story?id=20047743|publisher=ABC News|date=August 23, 2013}} Zimmerman's parents said that they too had received a news|last=Gutman|first=Matt|title=George Zimmerman Emerged From Hiding for Truck Crash civil case against Zimmerman|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|date=July 14, 2013|accessdate=July 14, 2013}} Within hours, 130,000 people had signed the petition.{{cite news|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/local/trayvon-martin/os-thousands-sign-tayvon-martin-petition,0,7105798.story|title=130K sign NAACP petition calling for DOJ investigation into Trayvon Martin shooting|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=July 14, 2013|accessdate=July 14, 2013}} During a speech at to the NAACP, Attorney General [[Eric Holder]] stated that the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] was continuing to investigate Zimmerman for civil rights violations after the verdict, and also criticized existing "stand-your-ground" laws. Holder's speech was denounced by the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] and Florida Governor [[Rick Scott]].{{cite news|title=NRA blasts Holder for attacking 'stand-your-ground' laws after Zimmerman verdict|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/07/17/nra-blasts-holder-for-attacking-stand-your-ground-laws-after-zimmerman-verdict/|publisher=[[Fox News Channel]]|accessdate=July 17, 2013|date=July California|last=Jacques-Wolfgang|first=Ben|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/jul/16/george-zimmerman-aftermath-more-dozen-arrested-vio/|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=July 17,
